name: Wattala

title: Chinese government provides $60 million grant to Sri Lanka for low-income housing through ETCA
description:
On May 16, 2017, the Chinese Government and the Government of Sri Lanka signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ECTA) that committed $60 million in grant funding for the development of 2,000 low income housing units.
 In August 2019, Sri Lanka’s Cabinet of Ministers identified the areas where these housing units will be constructed: The Divisional Secretariat Divisions of Moratuwa, Peliagoda, Thimbirigasyaya and Maharagama and land areas in Peliyagoda and Maharagama. However, as of late 2019, this project had still not yet entered implementation. 
 In April 9, 2018, Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) for this project was signed. The Urban Development Authority (UDA) would allocate lands for the construction of these houses.
 STAFF_NOTE: Additional information about the ETCA specifically could not be found.
sources: http://lk.chineseembassy.org/eng/xwdt/t1470918.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/index.php?option=com_rmobilization&view=resource_project&category_id=1&sub_category_id=1&searchby=donor_type&donor_id=4&today=2018-10-23&Itemid=321&lang=en, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/9fuzzplikl2gkpa/housing%20development%20for%20low%20income%20groups%20%282000%20units%29.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://english.utvnews.lk/156473/ , Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.dropbox.com/s/ekfp1xme8y9yz7j/Construction%20of%202000%20housing%20units%20under%20the%20Chinese%20Aid%20Programme%20for%20the%20low%20income%20people.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.dailymirror.lk/breaking_news/China-to-construct-2000-houses-for-low-income-families-in-Colombo/108-165169, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.erd.gov.lk/index.php?option=com_rmobilization&view=resource_project&category_id=2&sub_category_id=3&searchby=donor_type&donor_id=43&today=2019-10-17&Itemid=323&lang=en , Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
GEO_notes: Colombo district is coded since all of the areas that received funding are located in the Colombo District

title: China grants 62.24M yuan to Sri Lanka for extending fishery harbors
description: In 2010, China Harbour Engineering began work on the extension of fishery harbour projects in Sri Lanka at a cost of 62.24 million yuan. In 2011, the construction was finished. This project is an extension from a series of Chinese aid to Sri Lanka in response to the 2007 Sri Lanka floods.
sources: http://lk.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/201106/20110607593427.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: The project title is too vague. When reading the article, it became clear that only one fishery harbor was worked on during this project: Panadura Fishing Port. The port is located in Colombo District according to source 1.
name: Moratuwa

title: Chinese Government provides $18.2 million grant for post-tsunami reconstruction of Panadura, Beruwela and Kudawela fishing harbors
description:
On February 21, 2005, Chinese Government and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $18,207,786 grant agreement for the post-tsunami reconstruction of fishing harbors in Panadura, Beruwela and Kudawela (on the country’s western and southern coasts). 
 China Harbour Engineering Company was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began in 2005, and the project was completed on December 28, 2007. 
 STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese Government reportedly contributed $63 million in total for tsunami relief projects. Most of the individual projects that the Chinese Government financed are captured in AidData’s dataset and linked to Project ID #41811.

title: China Development Bank provides $54.8 million loan for Katana Water Supply Project
description:
On August 21, 2017, China Development Bank and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $54.8 million loan agreement for the Katana Water Supply Project (WSP). The purpose of this project is to provide safe drinking water via pipes to all 45 Grama Niladdhari divisions in Katana Divisional Secretariat, which covers 50% of the population in that area. Loan details are unknown.
 The project involves the construction of three towers at Bambukuliya, Ewariwatta and Thibirigaskatuwa, and the laying of transmission and distribution mains and supplying and supplying and installation of pumps. It is expected to take three years and cost a total of $64.5 million. The remaining $9.7 million is being provided by the Bank of Ceylon, a state-owned commercial bank in Sri Lanka. 
 The Sri Lanka National Water Supply & Drainage Board is overseeing implementation of this project. The project commencement date was August 21, 2017. As of March 30, 2019, it had achieved a "physical progress" rate of 43.7%. 
 Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 阿塔纳水厂项目目. This project is one of the four water supply projects under implementation in Sri Lanka funded by the China Development Bank. The other three projects are: Project #54435 (Gampaha, Attanagalla and Minuwangoda Integrated Water Supply Scheme), Project #53567 (Thambuttegama Water Supply Project), and Project #53568 (Valachchenai Water Supply Project and Banadarawela, Diyathalawa and Haputhale Water Supply Project).
sources: http://www.erd.gov.lk/index.php?option=com_rmobilization&view=resource_project&category_id=1&sub_category_id=1&searchby=donor_type&donor_id=4&today=2018-10-23&Itemid=321&lang=en, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/images/Publications/ERDReport2017/ERDReport2017-English.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=97:recently-signed-water-projects-china-division&catid=30&lang=en&Itemid=225, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/1blaikkvx68ec6r/Katana%20Water%20Supply%20Project.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/hmcek875exwg817/dec_detail.pdf?dl=0, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:CuBjXQY7uOMJ:www.pmm.gov.lk/resources/Progress%2520of%2520Large%2520scale%2520projects%2520as%2520at%252030th%2520September%25202018.pdf+&cd=1&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=us, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://www.cmec.com/xwzx/mtbd/201911/t20191104_225718.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://web.archive.org/web/20180107040947/http://www.erd.gov.lk/files/Parliament%20Question%20-%20Export%20Credit%2022.052014.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: Coded the Gampaha district since the Katana Divisional Secretariat is a Divisional Secretariat of the Gampaha District. The towers in Bambukuliya and Thibirigaskatuwa are both in the Gampaha District
name: Katana

title: China Eximbank provides $66.783 million buyer’s credit loan for Section A4 of the Colombo-Katunayake Expressway (CKE) Project (Linked to Project ID#71664, #71667, and #71670)
description:
On August 6, 2009, China Eximbank and the Government of Sri Lanka signed four separate buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreements for the Colombo-Katunayake Expressway (CKE) Project: a $70.042 million BCL for Section A1 of the CKE Project, a $63.574 million BCL for Section A2 of the CKE Project, a $47.801 million BCL for Section A3 of the CKE Project, and a $66.783 million BCL for Section A3 of the CKE Project. Each of these China Eximbank BCLs carry the following terms: 6.3% interest rate, 15-year maturity, 3-year grace period, 0.3% management fee, 0.3% commitment fee, and a 6% exposure fee. 
The objective of the CKE Project was to design and build a toll-charging four lane expressway that is 25.8 kilometers in length. Section A1 of the CKE Project involved the construction of the 0km-4.5km (0+000 to 4 +500) segment of the expressway. Section A2 of the CKE Project involved the construction of the 4.5km-10.9km (4+500 to 10+900) segment of the expressway. Section A3 of the CKE Project involved the construction of the 10.9km-16.8km (10+900 to 16+800) segment of the expressway. Section A4 of the CKE Project involved the construction of the 16.8km-25.8km (16+800 to 25+800) segment of the expressway. Project ID#71664 captures the $70.042 million BCL for Section A1 of the CKE Project. Project ID#71667 captures the $63.574 million BCL for Section A2 of the CKE Project. Project ID#71670 captures the $47.801 million BCL for Section A3 of the CKE Project. This project captures the $66.783 million BCL for Section A4 of the CKE Project. 
A contract for the construction of the CKE was initially awarded in October 2000 to a Korean construction company, but it was subsequently terminated in 2003. Then, in 2008, China Metallurgical Group Corporation was awarded a turnkey contract to construct the CKE. The proceeds from the four China Eximbank BCLs were used to pay China Metallurgical Group Corporation for its work on the A1, A2, A3, and A4 Sections of the CKE. 
The project commenced on August 18, 2009. It was completed and the CKE was opened for public use on October 27, 2013. The CKE links the Sri Lankan capital Colombo with Bandaranaike International Airport, Katunayake and Negombo. The highway has three lanes each way from Colombo to Peliyagoda, and two lanes each way from Peliyagoda to Katunayake. The speed limit is 80 km/h (50 mph) for the first eight kilometers (5.0 mi) and 100 km/h (62 mph) for the rest of the road. The CKE has 42 bridges and 88 culverts including a 480-meter long viaduct at Hunupitiya and an 800-meter viaduct at Katunayake. The opening of the expressway has allowed people to travel between Colombo, the commercial capital of Sri Lanka and Katunayake, the major international airport of Sri Lanka, within 15 minutes. 
STAFF_NOTE: The CKE is also known as the E03 expressway. Some sources identify the maturities of the China Eximbank BCLs as 16 years and the grace periods as 14 years. The objective of the Colombo-Katunayake Expressway (CKE) Project was to design and build a toll-charging four lane expressway that is 25.8 kilometers in length. The CKE links the Sri Lankan capital Colombo with Bandaranaike International Airport, Katunayake and Negombo. The highway has three lanes each way from Colombo to Peliyagoda, and two lanes each way from Peliyagoda to Katunayake.
sources: https://www.cbsl.gov.lk/sites/default/files/cbslweb_documents/statistics/mbt/Monthly_Bulletin_August_2009.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.treasury.gov.lk/documents/10181/12882/2013/99ec4ce9-183d-40ea-abfa-8331cdeee19d?version=1.0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.auditorgeneral.gov.lk/web/images/audit-reports/upload/2013/project_2013/ColomboKattunayakaExprees-wayE.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.auditorgeneral.gov.lk/web/images/audit-reports/upload/2014/Project/ColomboKatunayakaExpressWayProject2013E.pdf , Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/tguhlze1ys9l8ex/Colombo%20Katunayake%20Expressway%20%28A1%20%2C%20A2%20%2C%20A3%20%26%20A4%29.pdf?dl=0 , Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.mcc.com.cn/mccen/csr/hse/347748/index.html , Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.auditorgeneral.gov.lk/web/images/audit-reports/upload/2015/Projects_2015/4-XII-project/Colombo--Katunayake-Expressway-Project-E.pdf , Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.mcc.com.cn/mccen/focus/_325415/342031/index.html , Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E03_expressway_(Sri_Lanka) , Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.mcc.com.cn/mcc/_132154/_132572/231644/index.html , Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/colombo-katunayake-expressway-construction/d75b954f-1689-4ca5-9c0b-543258ca8505/ , Other; https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/439836093#map=14/7.0275/79.8914, Other; https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/336107413#map=11/6.9557/79.8832 , Other; https://www.google.com/maps/place/Colombo+-+Katunayake+Expy,+Sri+Lanka/@7.0587412,79.8444847,13z/data=!4m5!3m4!1s0x3ae2f1cb99359c6d:0xbb5ae225f130579!8m2!3d7.0587412!4d79.8795036 , Other; http://www.rda.gov.lk/supported/maps/expressway_network_as_at_2019_11_07.jpg, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: Colombo is coded in this row. The CKE runs through Colombo and Gampaha Districts. However, I can find no information as to which parts were built in each section so I have to code up to both districts even though the lengths don't match. Section 4
name: Katana

name: Katana

title: China Development Bank provides $102.5 million loan for Thambuttegama Water Supply Project
description: On August 21, 2017, China Development Bank and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $102.5 million loan agreement for the Thambuttegama Water Supply Project (WSP). The goal of this project is to provide safe drinking water via pipes to all 45 Grama Niladdhari divisions in Katana Divisional Secretariat covering 50% of the population in the area (similar to Project ID #53566). To do so, the project will, over 3 years, construct a water intake structure with a capacity of 42,000 m3/day, a water treatment plant of 18,000m3/day, a ground reservoir of 1,500 m3 capacity, a raw water and treated water transmission mains totaling up to an approximate length of 50 Km, elevated towers of 1,500 m3 capacity, a distribution network of 135 KM, and facilities to operate and maintain the water supply scheme. The project is expected to commence operations in 2021 and is in the tender evaluation stage as of March 2018. The project is being implemented by the Sri Lanka National Water Supply & Drainage Board. According to a March 2018 Sri Lanka news source, the Sri Lanka National Water Supply & Drainage Board Assistant General Manager for the North Central Province Sudath Ratnayake indicated that the CDB loan for this project carries an interest rate of 1-1.5 per cent plus London Inter Bank Offered Rate (LIBOR) and a maturity of 15 years. The interest rate is coded based on the 6-Month LIBOR rate at time of signing of the loan agreement. The average 6 month LIBOR (USD) for August 2017 was 1.454%. The least concessional base interest rate from the 1-1.5 per cent range was used to calculate the total interest rate. The total interest rate is therefore coded as 1.5% + 1.454%, or 2.954%. The total project is expected to cost $120.5 million; the remaining $18 million will be provided by the Bank of Ceylon, a state-owned, commercial bank in Sri Lanka. This project entered implementation on August 21, 2017. As of September 30, 2018, it had achieved a 'physical progress' rate of 4%. Staff Note: This project is one of the four water supply projects under implementation in Sri Lanka funded by the China Development Bank. Thambuttegama is sometimes spelled 'Thabuttegama'. The other three projects are: Project ID# 54435 (Gampaha, Attanagalla and Minuwangoda Integrated Water Supply Scheme), Project ID# 53566 (Katana Water Supply Project), Project ID# 53568 (Valachchenai Water Supply Project and Banadarawela, Diyathalawa and Haputhale Water Supply Project).
sources: http://www.erd.gov.lk/index.php?option=com_rmobilization&view=resource_project&category_id=1&sub_category_id=1&searchby=donor_type&donor_id=4&today=2018-10-23&Itemid=321&lang=en, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/images/Publications/ERDReport2017/ERDReport2017-English.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://mirrorcitizen.dailymirror.lk/2018/03/06/thambuttegama-farmers-losing-their-calm-before-the-storm/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.lankanewspapers.com/2018/03/05/suspended-tambuttegama-drinking-water-project-battle-water/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.erd.gov.lk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=97:recently-signed-water-projects-china-division&catid=30&lang=en&Itemid=225, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/emp5gvkddad3lsw/Thambuttegama%20Water%20Supply%20Project.pdf?dl=0, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); https://www.facebook.com/pages/category/Government-Organization/Thambuttegama-Water-Supply-Project-1947240748662935/, Social Media, including Unofficial Blogs; https://web.archive.org/web/20180107040947/http://www.erd.gov.lk/files/Parliament%20Question%20-%20Export%20Credit%2022.052014.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/hmcek875exwg817/dec_detail.pdf?dl=0, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/index.php?option=com_rmobilization&view=resource_project&category_id=1&sub_category_id=1&searchby=donor_type&donor_id=9&today=2019-10-06&Itemid=321&lang=en, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/index.php?option=com_rmobilization&view=resource_project&category_id=1&sub_category_id=1&searchby=donor_type&donor_id=12&today=2019-10-17&Itemid=321&lang=en, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: The project description and sources state that the project is designed to bring water to all 45 Grama Niladdhari divisions in Katana Divisional Secretariat. Grama Niladdhari divisions are classified as ADM4s, while Divisional Secretariats are classified as ADM3s. As our methodology states that we are coding to the ADM2 level, I found which ADM2 Katana is located in. I checked that it was located in Gampaha District by checking it on Wikipedia.
name: Katana

title: China Eximbank provides $63.574 million buyer’s credit loan for Section A2 of the Colombo-Katunayake Expressway (CKE) Project (Linked to Project ID#71664, #71670, and #71672)
description:
On August 6, 2009, China Eximbank and the Government of Sri Lanka signed four separate buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreements for the Colombo-Katunayake Expressway (CKE) Project: a $70.042 million BCL for Section A1 of the CKE Project, a $63.574 million BCL for Section A2 of the CKE Project, a $47.801 million BCL for Section A3 of the CKE Project, and a $66.783 million BCL for Section A3 of the CKE Project. Each of these China Eximbank BCLs carry the following terms: 6.3% interest rate, 15-year maturity, 3-year grace period, 0.3% management fee, 0.3% commitment fee, and a 6% exposure fee. 
 The objective of the CKE Project was to design and build a toll-charging four lane expressway that is 25.8 kilometers in length. Section A1 of the CKE Project involved the construction of the 0km-4.5km (0+000 to 4 +500) segment of the expressway. Section A2 of the CKE Project involved the construction of the 4.5km-10.9km (4+500 to 10+900) segment of the expressway. Section A3 of the CKE Project involved the construction of the 10.9km-16.8km (10+900 to 16+800) segment of the expressway. Section A4 of the CKE Project involved the construction of the 16.8km-25.8km (16+800 to 25+800) segment of the expressway. Project ID#71664 captures the $70.042 million BCL for Section A1 of the CKE Project. This project captures the $63.574 million BCL for Section A2 of the CKE Project. Project ID#71670 captures the $47.801 million BCL for Section A3 of the CKE Project. Project ID#71672 captures the $66.783 million BCL for Section A4 of the CKE Project. 
 A contract for the construction of the CKE was initially awarded in October 2000 to a Korean construction company, but it was subsequently terminated in 2003. Then, in 2008, China Metallurgical Group Corporation was awarded a turnkey contract to construct the CKE. The proceeds from the four China Eximbank BCLs were used to pay China Metallurgical Group Corporation for its work on the A1, A2, A3, and A4 Sections of the CKE. 
 The project commenced on August 18, 2009. It was completed and the CKE was opened for public use on October 27, 2013. The CKE links the Sri Lankan capital Colombo with Bandaranaike International Airport, Katunayake and Negombo. The highway has three lanes each way from Colombo to Peliyagoda, and two lanes each way from Peliyagoda to Katunayake. The speed limit is 80 km/h (50 mph) for the first eight kilometers (5.0 mi) and 100 km/h (62 mph) for the rest of the road. The CKE has 42 bridges and 88 culverts including a 480-meter long viaduct at Hunupitiya and an 800-meter viaduct at Katunayake. The opening of the expressway has allowed people to travel between Colombo, the commercial capital of Sri Lanka and Katunayake, the major international airport of Sri Lanka, within 15 minutes. 
 STAFF_NOTE: The CKE is also known as the E03 expressway. Some sources identify the maturities of the China Eximbank BCLs as 16 years and the grace periods as 14 years. The objective of the Colombo-Katunayake Expressway (CKE) Project was to design and build a toll-charging four lane expressway that is 25.8 kilometers in length. The CKE links the Sri Lankan capital Colombo with Bandaranaike International Airport, Katunayake and Negombo. The highway has three lanes each way from Colombo to Peliyagoda, and two lanes each way from Peliyagoda to Katunayake.
sources: https://silo.tips/download/public-investment-supported-by-export-credit, Other; https://www.cbsl.gov.lk/sites/default/files/cbslweb_documents/statistics/mbt/Monthly_Bulletin_August_2009.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.treasury.gov.lk/documents/10181/12882/2013/99ec4ce9-183d-40ea-abfa-8331cdeee19d?version=1.0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.auditorgeneral.gov.lk/web/images/audit-reports/upload/2013/project_2013/ColomboKattunayakaExprees-wayE.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.auditorgeneral.gov.lk/web/images/audit-reports/upload/2014/Project/ColomboKatunayakaExpressWayProject2013E.pdf , Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.auditorgeneral.gov.lk/web/images/audit-reports/upload/2014/Project/ColomboKatunayakaExpressWayProject2013E.pdf , Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.mcc.com.cn/mccen/csr/hse/347748/index.html , Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.auditorgeneral.gov.lk/web/images/audit-reports/upload/2015/Projects_2015/4-XII-project/Colombo--Katunayake-Expressway-Project-E.pdf , Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.mcc.com.cn/mccen/focus/_325415/342031/index.html , Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E03_expressway_(Sri_Lanka) , Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.mcc.com.cn/mcc/_132154/_132572/231644/index.html , Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
GEO_notes: Gampaha district and Colombo district are coded for this project since the expressway runs from Colombo, which is located in Colombo District, to katunayake, which is located in Gampaha district (Colombo)
Christian.Notes: all the actual districts the A3 runs thru
name: Kelaniya

title: China provided an RMB 48 million grant to Sri Lanka for the Signalization of Welikada Intersection and Improvement of Colombo-Kandy Road Section from Kiribathgoda to Kadawatha Project
description:
On December 18, 2007, Sri Lanka’s Road Development Authority (RDA) signed two contracts with Shanxi Construction Engineering (Group) Corporation (CSCE): one contract worth RMB 45 million for improvement of 2.3 km from Kiribathgoda to Kadawatha of Colombo-Kandy road and for and another contract worth RMB 3 million for the signalization of Welikada Intersection. Both of these contracts were supported by grant assistance from the Chinese Government. 
 Third Railway Survey and Design Institute of China (renamed as China Railway Design Corporation (CRDC) ) was responsible for the design of the road. CSCE was responsible for construction of the road. Through this project, a 2.3 km road segment from Gala Junction Bridge at Kiribathgoda to Kadawatha of Colombo Kandy Road (A001) was widened to four lanes with a 1.2 m centre median, a 1.4 m hard shoulder and a 1.6 m soft shoulder both sides. The project was completed on July 12, 2011.
sources: http://www.parliament.lk/uploads/documents/paperspresented/annual_report_road_development_authority_2011.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.parliament.lk/papers_presented/21092012/annual_report_ministry_of_ports_aviation_2010.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.hovael.com/2018/05/15/highway-project-to-aid-sri-lanka-road-improvement-engineering-for-section-from-kiribathgoda-to-kadawatha-from-colombo-to-kandy-2-3km-china-beijing-international-pvt-ltd-kopiyawatte-road-colombo/, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: The bridge and expansion are located on 2km stretch that is located in Colombo.
name: Kelaniya

title: Chinese government provides $60 million grant to Sri Lanka for low-income housing through ETCA
description:
On May 16, 2017, the Chinese Government and the Government of Sri Lanka signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ECTA) that committed $60 million in grant funding for the development of 2,000 low income housing units.
 In August 2019, Sri Lanka’s Cabinet of Ministers identified the areas where these housing units will be constructed: The Divisional Secretariat Divisions of Moratuwa, Peliagoda, Thimbirigasyaya and Maharagama and land areas in Peliyagoda and Maharagama. However, as of late 2019, this project had still not yet entered implementation. 
 In April 9, 2018, Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) for this project was signed. The Urban Development Authority (UDA) would allocate lands for the construction of these houses.
 STAFF_NOTE: Additional information about the ETCA specifically could not be found.
sources: http://lk.chineseembassy.org/eng/xwdt/t1470918.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/index.php?option=com_rmobilization&view=resource_project&category_id=1&sub_category_id=1&searchby=donor_type&donor_id=4&today=2018-10-23&Itemid=321&lang=en, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/9fuzzplikl2gkpa/housing%20development%20for%20low%20income%20groups%20%282000%20units%29.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://english.utvnews.lk/156473/ , Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.dropbox.com/s/ekfp1xme8y9yz7j/Construction%20of%202000%20housing%20units%20under%20the%20Chinese%20Aid%20Programme%20for%20the%20low%20income%20people.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.dailymirror.lk/breaking_news/China-to-construct-2000-houses-for-low-income-families-in-Colombo/108-165169, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.erd.gov.lk/index.php?option=com_rmobilization&view=resource_project&category_id=2&sub_category_id=3&searchby=donor_type&donor_id=43&today=2019-10-17&Itemid=323&lang=en , Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
GEO_notes: Colombo district is coded since all of the areas that received funding are located in the Colombo District

title: China opens Confucius Institute at the University of Kelaniya
description: Confucius Institute at University of Kelaniya, Sri Lanka was founded in 2007. Since September 2011, it has cooperated with Chongqing Normal University in China. At present, there are 220 square meters for class room and office. Person of contact: Nedalagamuwe Dhammadinna Address: Confucius Institute, Faculty of Humanity, University of Kelaniya, Dalugama, Kelaniya11600, Sri Lanka Tel: +94-714412168 Fax: +94-112911485 E-mail: dhammadinna@hotmail.com

title: China Eximbank provides $47.801 million buyer’s credit loan for Section A3 of the Colombo-Katunayake Expressway (CKE) Project (Linked to Project ID#71664, #71667, and #71672)

 STAFF_NOTE: The CKE is also known as the E03 expressway. Some sources identify the maturities of the China Eximbank BCLs as 16 years and the grace periods as 14 years. The objective of the Colombo-Katunayake Expressway (CKE) Project was to design and build a toll-charging four lane expressway that is 25.8 kilometers in length. The CKE links the Sri Lankan capital Colombo with Bandaranaike International Airport, Katunayake and Negombo. The highway has three lanes each way from Colombo to Peliyagoda, and two lanes each way from Peliyagoda to Katunayake.

title: China Eximbank provides $63.574 million buyer’s credit loan for Section A2 of the Colombo-Katunayake Expressway (CKE) Project (Linked to Project ID#71664, #71670, and #71672)
description:
On August 6, 2009, China Eximbank and the Government of Sri Lanka signed four separate buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreements for the Colombo-Katunayake Expressway (CKE) Project: a $70.042 million BCL for Section A1 of the CKE Project, a $63.574 million BCL for Section A2 of the CKE Project, a $47.801 million BCL for Section A3 of the CKE Project, and a $66.783 million BCL for Section A3 of the CKE Project. Each of these China Eximbank BCLs carry the following terms: 6.3% interest rate, 15-year maturity, 3-year grace period, 0.3% management fee, 0.3% commitment fee, and a 6% exposure fee. 
 The objective of the CKE Project was to design and build a toll-charging four lane expressway that is 25.8 kilometers in length. Section A1 of the CKE Project involved the construction of the 0km-4.5km (0+000 to 4 +500) segment of the expressway. Section A2 of the CKE Project involved the construction of the 4.5km-10.9km (4+500 to 10+900) segment of the expressway. Section A3 of the CKE Project involved the construction of the 10.9km-16.8km (10+900 to 16+800) segment of the expressway. Section A4 of the CKE Project involved the construction of the 16.8km-25.8km (16+800 to 25+800) segment of the expressway. Project ID#71664 captures the $70.042 million BCL for Section A1 of the CKE Project. This project captures the $63.574 million BCL for Section A2 of the CKE Project. Project ID#71670 captures the $47.801 million BCL for Section A3 of the CKE Project. Project ID#71672 captures the $66.783 million BCL for Section A4 of the CKE Project. 
 A contract for the construction of the CKE was initially awarded in October 2000 to a Korean construction company, but it was subsequently terminated in 2003. Then, in 2008, China Metallurgical Group Corporation was awarded a turnkey contract to construct the CKE. The proceeds from the four China Eximbank BCLs were used to pay China Metallurgical Group Corporation for its work on the A1, A2, A3, and A4 Sections of the CKE. 
 The project commenced on August 18, 2009. It was completed and the CKE was opened for public use on October 27, 2013. The CKE links the Sri Lankan capital Colombo with Bandaranaike International Airport, Katunayake and Negombo. The highway has three lanes each way from Colombo to Peliyagoda, and two lanes each way from Peliyagoda to Katunayake. The speed limit is 80 km/h (50 mph) for the first eight kilometers (5.0 mi) and 100 km/h (62 mph) for the rest of the road. The CKE has 42 bridges and 88 culverts including a 480-meter long viaduct at Hunupitiya and an 800-meter viaduct at Katunayake. The opening of the expressway has allowed people to travel between Colombo, the commercial capital of Sri Lanka and Katunayake, the major international airport of Sri Lanka, within 15 minutes. 
 STAFF_NOTE: The CKE is also known as the E03 expressway. Some sources identify the maturities of the China Eximbank BCLs as 16 years and the grace periods as 14 years. The objective of the Colombo-Katunayake Expressway (CKE) Project was to design and build a toll-charging four lane expressway that is 25.8 kilometers in length. The CKE links the Sri Lankan capital Colombo with Bandaranaike International Airport, Katunayake and Negombo. The highway has three lanes each way from Colombo to Peliyagoda, and two lanes each way from Peliyagoda to Katunayake.

GEO_notes: Gampaha district and Colombo district are coded for this project since the expressway runs from Colombo, which is located in Colombo District, to katunayake, which is located in Gampaha district (Colombo)

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 12.8 million grant for Supply of MRI Scanner to Colombo North Teaching Hospital Ragama Project
description: On March 26, 2015, the Chinese Government and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a RMB 12.8 million grant agreement for the Supply of MRI Scanner to Colombo North Teaching Hospital Ragama Project. This project involves the provision of one MRI Scanner to expedite diagnostic and medical service provision at Colombo North Teaching Hospital (CNTH), which is located at Ragama in the Gampaha District. CNTH is located 18 km away from the capital of Sri Lanka. Its exact locational coordinates are available at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Teaching+Hospitil+Ragama/@7.0286216,79.9242517,15z/data=!4m5!3m4!1s0x0:0x2b3da3bac3b70d15!8m2!3d7.0286216!4d79.9242517 As of December 31, 2017, this project had achieved a physical progress rate of 20%. According to the Department of External Resources, the project was completed on April 20, 2019.

title: China Eximbank provides $73.21 million buyer’s credit loan for Northern Road Rehabilitation Project (C7) (Linked to Project ID#71641, #71642, #71643, #71644, #71645, #71646)
description:
On April 29, 2011, China Eximbank and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $73.21 million buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreement [No. BLA 201112] for the Northern Road Rehabilitation Project (C7). This BCL carries the following terms: 6-month LIBOR plus a 2% margin, 15-year maturity, 3-year grace period, 0.5% management fee, 0.7% commitment fee, and a 6% exposure fee. The average 6 Month LIBOR rate in April 2011 was 0.442%. Total interest rate is therefore coded as 0.442% + 2.0%, or 2.442%. 
 The purpose of the Northern Road Rehabilitation Project (C7) was to rehabilitate and improved the Puttalam-Marichchikade-Mannar Road (B379). C7 stands for Contract 7. China Harbour Engineering Company Ltd was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The project commenced on August 24, 2012. It was originally scheduled for completion on February 23, 2015. However, it was completed ahead of schedule on November 26, 2014. As a result of this project, travel times between Jaffna and the Western and Southern Provinces were significantly reduced. 
 STAFF_NOTE: This project is also known as the Rehabilitation & Improvement of 113km Length of Puttalam-Marichchikade-Mannar Road (B379) Project.
sources: https://www.parliament.lk/uploads/documents/paperspresented/annual-report-road-development-authority-2012.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.rda.gov.lk/supported/maps/expressway_network_as_at_2019_11_07.jpg, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/images/pdf/disbursements_in_2013_jan_to_dec.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.treasury.gov.lk/documents/10181/12882/2013/99ec4ce9-183d-40ea-abfa-8331cdeee19d?version=1.0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://docplayer.net/22736118-Public-investment-supported-by-export-credit.html , Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://cecb.lk/project/Completed%20Projects/Roads%20and%20Bridges/Rehabilitation%20of%20Roads%20in%20the%20North.html , Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.auditorgeneral.gov.lk/web/images/NothernRoadRehabilitationProject64Km201E.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://web.archive.org/web/20180107040947/http://www.erd.gov.lk/files/Parliament%20Question%20-%20Export%20Credit%2022.052014.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.auditorgeneral.gov.lk/web/images/audit-reports/upload/2014/Project/NorthernRoadRehabilitationProjectPuttalamMarichchikadeMannarRaod2014E.pdf , Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: Puttalam District and Mannar District are coded for this project since the road connects Puttalam and Mannar, used google maps but couldn't find the exact road (Puttalam)
Christian.Notes: all the actual districts the B379 runs thru
name: Vanathavilluwa

title: China grants 62.24M yuan to Sri Lanka for extending fishery harbors
description: In 2010, China Harbour Engineering began work on the extension of fishery harbour projects in Sri Lanka at a cost of 62.24 million yuan. In 2011, the construction was finished. This project is an extension from a series of Chinese aid to Sri Lanka in response to the 2007 Sri Lanka floods.
sources: http://lk.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/201106/20110607593427.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: The project title is too vague. When reading the article, it became clear that only one fishery harbor was worked on during this project: Panadura Fishing Port. The port is located in Colombo District according to source 1.
name: Panadura

title: Chinese Government provides $18.2 million grant for post-tsunami reconstruction of Panadura, Beruwela and Kudawela fishing harbors
description:
On February 21, 2005, Chinese Government and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $18,207,786 grant agreement for the post-tsunami reconstruction of fishing harbors in Panadura, Beruwela and Kudawela (on the country’s western and southern coasts). 
 China Harbour Engineering Company was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began in 2005, and the project was completed on December 28, 2007. 
 STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese Government reportedly contributed $63 million in total for tsunami relief projects. Most of the individual projects that the Chinese Government financed are captured in AidData’s dataset and linked to Project ID #41811.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=SCMP000020050404e1450002d&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAPP0020071229e3ct001e2&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://archives.dailynews.lk/2006/09/04/fin02.asp, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.parliament.lk/uploads/documents/paperspresented/annual_report_ceylon_fishery_harbours_corporation_2010.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.ics2011.pl/artic/SP64_1245-1249_D.P.C.Laknath.pdf, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); http://www.treasury.gov.lk/reports/annualreport/annualReport2007-eng.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=XNEWS00020050120e11k00566&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/du/article.aspx/?accessionno=BSWEEK0020050107e11700001&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=&cat=a, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.dropbox.com/s/zbodvq1t9w12kyc/PUBDOC2188_document.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://web.archive.org/web/20171013145057/http://www.treasury.gov.lk/documents/10181/12870/2005/a06436fe-113d-41ae-b4c9-54bd2319786c, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://reliefweb.int/report/sri-lanka/china-hands-over-tsunami-projects-sri-lanka , Media Report, including Wikileaks
factiva_sources: https://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=SCMP000020050404e1450002d&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/aa/?ref=BBCAPP0020071229e3ct001e2&pp=1&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=XNEWS00020050120e11k00566&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/du/article.aspx/?accessionno=BSWEEK0020050107e11700001&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=&cat=a, Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: The CEYLON FISHERY HABOURS CORPORATION 2010 Annual Report states that the government of China "funded the reconstruction work of the Panadura, Beruwala, and Kudawella fishery harbours." I was able to find each of the fishery harbours using google maps. Although Panadura Fishery Harbour has the name Panadura, it is located in the Moratuwa city, in the Colombo District. Coded using QGIS and GeoJSOn
name: Panadura

The CKE links the Sri Lankan capital Colombo with Bandaranaike International Airport, Katunayake and Negombo. The highway has three lanes each way from Colombo to Peliyagoda, and two lanes each way from Peliyagoda to Katunayake. The speed limit is 80 km/h (50 mph) for the first eight kilometers (5.0 mi) and 100 km/h (62 mph) for the rest of the road. The CKE has 42 bridges and 88 culverts including a 480-meter long viaduct at Hunupitiya and an 800-meter viaduct at Katunayake. The opening of the expressway has allowed people to travel between Colombo, the commercial capital of Sri Lanka and Katunayake, the major international airport of Sri Lanka, within 15 minutes. 
 STAFF_NOTE: The CKE is also known as the E03 expressway. Some sources identify the maturities of the China Eximbank BCLs as 16 years and the grace periods as 14 years. The objective of the Colombo-Katunayake Expressway (CKE) Project was to design and build a toll-charging four lane expressway that is 25.8 kilometers in length. The CKE links the Sri Lankan capital Colombo with Bandaranaike International Airport, Katunayake and Negombo. The highway has three lanes each way from Colombo to Peliyagoda, and two lanes each way from Peliyagoda to Katunayake.

title: China Eximbank provides $63.574 million buyer’s credit loan for Section A2 of the Colombo-Katunayake Expressway (CKE) Project (Linked to Project ID#71664, #71670, and #71672)
description:
On August 6, 2009, China Eximbank and the Government of Sri Lanka signed four separate buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreements for the Colombo-Katunayake Expressway (CKE) Project: a $70.042 million BCL for Section A1 of the CKE Project, a $63.574 million BCL for Section A2 of the CKE Project, a $47.801 million BCL for Section A3 of the CKE Project, and a $66.783 million BCL for Section A3 of the CKE Project. Each of these China Eximbank BCLs carry the following terms: 6.3% interest rate, 15-year maturity, 3-year grace period, 0.3% management fee, 0.3% commitment fee, and a 6% exposure fee. 
 The objective of the CKE Project was to design and build a toll-charging four lane expressway that is 25.8 kilometers in length. Section A1 of the CKE Project involved the construction of the 0km-4.5km (0+000 to 4 +500) segment of the expressway. Section A2 of the CKE Project involved the construction of the 4.5km-10.9km (4+500 to 10+900) segment of the expressway. Section A3 of the CKE Project involved the construction of the 10.9km-16.8km (10+900 to 16+800) segment of the expressway. Section A4 of the CKE Project involved the construction of the 16.8km-25.8km (16+800 to 25+800) segment of the expressway. Project ID#71664 captures the $70.042 million BCL for Section A1 of the CKE Project. This project captures the $63.574 million BCL for Section A2 of the CKE Project. Project ID#71670 captures the $47.801 million BCL for Section A3 of the CKE Project. Project ID#71672 captures the $66.783 million BCL for Section A4 of the CKE Project. 
 A contract for the construction of the CKE was initially awarded in October 2000 to a Korean construction company, but it was subsequently terminated in 2003. Then, in 2008, China Metallurgical Group Corporation was awarded a turnkey contract to construct the CKE. The proceeds from the four China Eximbank BCLs were used to pay China Metallurgical Group Corporation for its work on the A1, A2, A3, and A4 Sections of the CKE. 
 The project commenced on August 18, 2009. It was completed and the CKE was opened for public use on October 27, 2013. The CKE links the Sri Lankan capital Colombo with Bandaranaike International Airport, Katunayake and Negombo. The highway has three lanes each way from Colombo to Peliyagoda, and two lanes each way from Peliyagoda to Katunayake. The speed limit is 80 km/h (50 mph) for the first eight kilometers (5.0 mi) and 100 km/h (62 mph) for the rest of the road. The CKE has 42 bridges and 88 culverts including a 480-meter long viaduct at Hunupitiya and an 800-meter viaduct at Katunayake. The opening of the expressway has allowed people to travel between Colombo, the commercial capital of Sri Lanka and Katunayake, the major international airport of Sri Lanka, within 15 minutes. 
 STAFF_NOTE: The CKE is also known as the E03 expressway. Some sources identify the maturities of the China Eximbank BCLs as 16 years and the grace periods as 14 years. The objective of the Colombo-Katunayake Expressway (CKE) Project was to design and build a toll-charging four lane expressway that is 25.8 kilometers in length. The CKE links the Sri Lankan capital Colombo with Bandaranaike International Airport, Katunayake and Negombo. The highway has three lanes each way from Colombo to Peliyagoda, and two lanes each way from Peliyagoda to Katunayake.

name: Kolonnawa

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 46.8 million loan for Kelanitissa Diesel Tank Storage Farm Expansion Project
description:
On May 16, 2004, China Eximbank and the Ministry of Finance of the Government of Sri Lanka signed an RMB 46.8 million China Eximbank loan agreement for the Kelanitissa Diesel Tank Storage Farm Expansion Project. This loan carried a 2% interest rate. 
 The Ministry of Finance of the Government of Sri Lanka then used the proceeds from this China Eximbank loan to on-lend at a 10% interest rate to Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB), which is a state-owned electricity company that controls all major functions of electricity generation, transmission, distribution and retailing in Sri Lanka. This project involved the construction of two diesel storage tanks of 10,000 MT each at the Kelanithissa Power Station. This project started on September 23, 2004. It was completed on October 31, 2005. The implementing agency is China Huanqiu Contracting & Engineering Corporation (中国寰球工程公司).
 The Kelanitissa Power Station, which was commissioned in 2003, is located on the south bank of the Kelani River in the northern part of the city of Colombo, Sri Lanka. Its exact coordinates are available at http://globalenergyobservatory.org/geoid/40490 and https://www.google.com/maps/place/Kelanitissa+Power+Station/@6.9526629,79.8785059,15z/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x0:0x478dd69521e70eb1?sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwid0v3n2c_pAhUFoHIEHePIAmgQ_BIwDXoECBcQCw.
 STAFF_NOTE: This project is sometimes referred to as the Kelanitissa Diesel Storage Tank Project. Some sources refer to the face value of the loan as $5,608,646. However, this is likely a USD conversion of an RMB-denominated government concessional loan (GCL) from China Eximbank.

title: Chinese government provides $60 million grant to Sri Lanka for low-income housing through ETCA
description:
On May 16, 2017, the Chinese Government and the Government of Sri Lanka signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ECTA) that committed $60 million in grant funding for the development of 2,000 low income housing units.
 In August 2019, Sri Lanka’s Cabinet of Ministers identified the areas where these housing units will be constructed: The Divisional Secretariat Divisions of Moratuwa, Peliagoda, Thimbirigasyaya and Maharagama and land areas in Peliyagoda and Maharagama. However, as of late 2019, this project had still not yet entered implementation. 
 In April 9, 2018, Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) for this project was signed. The Urban Development Authority (UDA) would allocate lands for the construction of these houses.
 STAFF_NOTE: Additional information about the ETCA specifically could not be found.

title: CDB provides $500 million loan for Rehabilitation and Improvement of Priority Road Project 2 (PRP2) (Linked to Project ID #46971, #33402 and #39002)
description: On March 31, 2011, China Development Bank and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $500 million loan facility agreement (No. 4500062212011110472) for the Rehabilitation and Improvement of Priority Road Project 2 (PRP2). This loan carries the following terms: 15 year maturity, 4 year grace period, interest rate of 6-month LIBOR pus a 2.9% margin, 0.5% management fee, 3.26% risk (insurance) premium. The first tranche of escrow funding (worth $326 million) was received by the Central Bank of Sri Lanka on June 29, 2011 and second tranche of escrow funding (worth $174 million) was on 28th October 28, 2011. The total cost of the PRP2 was $556 million. 90% of the project cost was covered by CDB and approximately 10% of the project cost was provided by the Government of Sri Lanka. The purpose of the project to rehabilitate and improve 581 km in 20 roads, including 95 km of provincial roads in Nuwara Eliya district, construction of two flyovers and reconstruction and widening of 22 bridges under two components (see Development Performance Report Year End Review 2015 from the Sri Lanka Department of Project Management). The 24 project components listed below include the 20 road sections, the 2 flyovers, and the 2 bridge components. This project included 24 components: 1. Horawela-Pelawatte-Pitigala Road: 0.0 - 17.50 km 2. Horana-Anguruwatota-Aluthgama Road: 5.0 - 32.0 km (total length of 27.0 km) 3. Horawela-Pelawatta-Pitigala Road: 17.5 - 25.74 km (total length of 8.24 km) 4. Construction of a flyover at Mattala airport access road junction in Hambantota Hub Development. 5. Construction of a flyover at 100 feet road and bypass road junction in Hambantota Hub Development. 6. Reconstruction/widening of Bridges on Tiruwanaketiya-Agalawatta Road: 33.45 - 67.80 km (total length of 34.35 km) 7. Reconstruction/widening of Bridges on Horana-Anguruwayoya-Aluthgama Road: 5.0 - 32.0 km (total length of 27.0 km) 8. Thihagoda-Kamburupitiya-Mawarala-Kotapola Road: 23.0 - 67.0 km (total length of 44.0 km) 9. Hungama-Middeniya Road: 0.0 - 30.0 km 10. Nagoda-Kalawellawa-Bellapitiya Road: 27.0 - 57.0 km (total length of 30.0 km) This project included the following components in the Northern Zone (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 'Resource Mobilization'): 11. Kandy-Mahiyangana-Padiyathalawa Road: 93.15 - 102.28 km (total length of 9.13 km) 12. Badulla-Karamatiya-Andaulpotha Road: 0.0 - 48 km 13. Mahiyangana-Dimbulagala-Daukkane Road: 0.0 - 24.10 km 14. Bibile-Uraniya-Mahiyangana Road: 22.0 - 39.58 km (total length of 17.58 km) 15. Galkulama-Anuradhapura Road: 0.0 - 15.0 km & 16.0 - 16.64 km (total length of 15.64 km) 16. Kadahapoka-Rambawewa Road: 0.0 - 18.71 km 17. Kurunegala-Narammala-Madampe Road: 0.0 - 22.36 km 18. Galagedara-Rambukkana Road: 0.0 - 18.5 km 19. Tennekumbura-Rikillagaskada-Ragala Road: 20.2 - 73.64 km (total length of 53.44 km) 20. Uswetakeiyawa-Epamulla-Pamunugama Road: 0.0 - 8.05 km 21. Palaviya-Kalpitiya Road: 14.0 - 40.60 km (total length of 26.60 km) 22. Mahiyangana-Dimbulagala-Dalukkane Road: 24.10 - 72.8 km (total length of 48.7 km) 23. Manampitiya-Aralaganwila-Maduru Oya Road: 0.0 - 3.0 km 24. Provincial Roads in Nuwaraeliya District: 85.01 km. Xi'an Dagang Road Machinery Co. Ltd., China National Aero Technology International Engineering Corporation, and Hunan Construction Engineering Corporation were the three contractors responsible for project implementation. Implementation PRP2 began on June 28, 2011 and it was completed on December 31, 2014. Staff Note: The interest rate is coded based on 6-month LIBOR at time of signing of the loan agreement. The average 6-month LIBOR rate in March 2011 was 0.461%. The total interest rate is therefore coded as 0.461% + 2.90%, or 3.361%. The Priority Road Project had three phases; see Project ID #46971 (PRP1), Project ID #33402 (PRP3-Phase 1), and Project ID #39002 (PRP3-Phase 2) for more details.

title: CDB provides $300 million loan for Rehabilitation and Improvement of Priority Road Project 3 - Phase I (PRP3-I) (Linked to Project ID #46971, #39001 and #39002)
description: On March 11, 2014, China Development Bank (CDB) and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $300 million loan facility agreement [No. 4510201401100000245] for the Rehabilitation and Improvement of Priority Road Project 3 - Phase I (PRP3-I). This loan carried the following terms: 15 year maturity, 3 year grace period, interest rate of 6-month LIBOR plus a 2.95% margin, 0.5% management fee, and a 5% risk (insurance) premium. CDB deposited $300 million in an account controlled by the Central Bank of Sri Lanka on March 28, 2014. PRP3 Phase I was divided into two parts, A and B. The contractors for PRP3-Phase I (A) were China National Aero-Technology International Engineering (CATIC - ENG) and Xi'an Dagang Machinery Co. Ltd. The contractors for PRP3-Phase I (B) were CATIC and Hunan Construction Engineering Group Corporation (Hunan). Under PRP3- Phase I (A), 6 roads were rehabilitated: 1. Ratnapura - Palawela - Karawita Road: 00.00km - 21.28 km 2. Veyangoda -Ruwanwella Road: 12.4 km - 32.2 km (19.8 km total length). This section also included the rehabilitation of a bridge. 3. Meegahajandura-Kumaragama Road: 0.00 km - 8.8 km 4. Galle-Udugama Road: 0.00 km - 35.35 km 5. Hiniduma-Opatha-Pitabaddara Road: 0.00 km - 31.5 km. This section also included the rehabilitation of a bridge. 6. Mawanella-Hemmathagama-Gampola Road: 0.00 km - 26.00 km. Under PRP3 - Phase I (B), 6 roads were rehabilitated: 7. Kiriella-Nedurana-Eheliyagoda Road: 0.00 km - 14.75 km. Contractor: CATIC 8. Ratnapura-Wewelwatte Road: 0.00 km - 27.50 km. Contractor: CATIC 9. Kandy-Jaffna Road: 1.65 km - 3.9 km (2.25 km total length). Contractor: Hunan 10. Marawila-Udubaddawa Road: 0.00 km - 19.55 km. Contractor: Hunan 11. Rambukkana-Katupitiya Road (0.00 km - 9.81 km) and Dambokka-Katupitiya Road (0.00 km - 8.75 km). These two roads were rehabilitated at the same time and are considered the same project by the Sri Lanka Ministry of Highways and Investment. Contractor: Hunan 12. Ayagama-Egaloya Road: 0.00 km - 23.00 km. Contractor: CATIC. PRP3 Phase I commenced its activities on September 9, 2014 and it was scheduled to be completed by July 17, 2017. However, as of September 30, 2019, PRP3-II was still ongoing. Staff Note: The interest rate is coded based on the 6-month LIBOR at time of signing of the loan agreement. The average 6-month LIBOR rate in March 2014 was 0.331%. The total interest rate is therefore coded as 0.331% + 2.95%, or 3.281%. The Priority Road Project had three phases; see Project ID #46971 (PRP1), Project ID #39001 (PRP2), and Project ID #39002 (PRP3-Phase 2) for more details.

title: CDB provides $500 million loan for Rehabilitation and Improvement of Priority Road Project 2 (PRP2) (Linked to Project ID #46971, #33402 and #39002)
description: On March 31, 2011, China Development Bank and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $500 million loan facility agreement (No. 4500062212011110472) for the Rehabilitation and Improvement of Priority Road Project 2 (PRP2). This loan carries the following terms: 15 year maturity, 4 year grace period, interest rate of 6-month LIBOR pus a 2.9% margin, 0.5% management fee, 3.26% risk (insurance) premium. The first tranche of escrow funding (worth $326 million) was received by the Central Bank of Sri Lanka on June 29, 2011 and second tranche of escrow funding (worth $174 million) was on 28th October 28, 2011. The total cost of the PRP2 was $556 million. 90% of the project cost was covered by CDB and approximately 10% of the project cost was provided by the Government of Sri Lanka. The purpose of the project to rehabilitate and improve 581 km in 20 roads, including 95 km of provincial roads in Nuwara Eliya district, construction of two flyovers and reconstruction and widening of 22 bridges under two components (see Development Performance Report Year End Review 2015 from the Sri Lanka Department of Project Management). The 24 project components listed below include the 20 road sections, the 2 flyovers, and the 2 bridge components. This project included 24 components: 1. Horawela-Pelawatte-Pitigala Road: 0.0 - 17.50 km 2. Horana-Anguruwatota-Aluthgama Road: 5.0 - 32.0 km (total length of 27.0 km) 3. Horawela-Pelawatta-Pitigala Road: 17.5 - 25.74 km (total length of 8.24 km) 4. Construction of a flyover at Mattala airport access road junction in Hambantota Hub Development. 5. Construction of a flyover at 100 feet road and bypass road junction in Hambantota Hub Development. 6. Reconstruction/widening of Bridges on Tiruwanaketiya-Agalawatta Road: 33.45 - 67.80 km (total length of 34.35 km) 7. Reconstruction/widening of Bridges on Horana-Anguruwayoya-Aluthgama Road: 5.0 - 32.0 km (total length of 27.0 km) 8. Thihagoda-Kamburupitiya-Mawarala-Kotapola Road: 23.0 - 67.0 km (total length of 44.0 km) 9. Hungama-Middeniya Road: 0.0 - 30.0 km 10. Nagoda-Kalawellawa-Bellapitiya Road: 27.0 - 57.0 km (total length of 30.0 km) This project included the following components in the Northern Zone (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 'Resource Mobilization'): 11. Kandy-Mahiyangana-Padiyathalawa Road: 93.15 - 102.28 km (total length of 9.13 km) 12. Badulla-Karamatiya-Andaulpotha Road: 0.0 - 48 km 13. Mahiyangana-Dimbulagala-Daukkane Road: 0.0 - 24.10 km 14. Bibile-Uraniya-Mahiyangana Road: 22.0 - 39.58 km (total length of 17.58 km) 15. Galkulama-Anuradhapura Road: 0.0 - 15.0 km & 16.0 - 16.64 km (total length of 15.64 km) 16. Kadahapoka-Rambawewa Road: 0.0 - 18.71 km 17. Kurunegala-Narammala-Madampe Road: 0.0 - 22.36 km 18. Galagedara-Rambukkana Road: 0.0 - 18.5 km 19. Tennekumbura-Rikillagaskada-Ragala Road: 20.2 - 73.64 km (total length of 53.44 km) 20. Uswetakeiyawa-Epamulla-Pamunugama Road: 0.0 - 8.05 km 21. Palaviya-Kalpitiya Road: 14.0 - 40.60 km (total length of 26.60 km) 22. Mahiyangana-Dimbulagala-Dalukkane Road: 24.10 - 72.8 km (total length of 48.7 km) 23. Manampitiya-Aralaganwila-Maduru Oya Road: 0.0 - 3.0 km 24. Provincial Roads in Nuwaraeliya District: 85.01 km. Xi'an Dagang Road Machinery Co. Ltd., China National Aero Technology International Engineering Corporation, and Hunan Construction Engineering Corporation were the three contractors responsible for project implementation. Implementation PRP2 began on June 28, 2011 and it was completed on December 31, 2014. Staff Note: The interest rate is coded based on 6-month LIBOR at time of signing of the loan agreement. The average 6-month LIBOR rate in March 2011 was 0.461%. The total interest rate is therefore coded as 0.461% + 2.90%, or 3.361%. The Priority Road Project had three phases; see Project ID #46971 (PRP1), Project ID #33402 (PRP3-Phase 1), and Project ID #39002 (PRP3-Phase 2) for more details.

name: Kalutara

title: China Eximbank provides $494.03 preferential buyer’s credit for Phase III of the Outer Circular Highway Project (Kadawatha to Kerawalapitiya Section)
description:
On September 16, 2014, China Eximbank and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $494.03 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) agreement [No.PBC(2014) 15 Total No.(309)] for Phase III of the Outer Circular Highway Project (Kadawatha to Kerawalapitiya Section). This PBC carries the following terms: 2% interest rate. 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, 0.25% commitment fee, and a 0.25% management fee. 
The objective of the purpose of the project is to construct an expressway in the outskirts of Colombo which connects with the Southern Expressway and other national roads radiating from Colombo city in order to mitigate traffic congestion in the Colombo Metropolitan Region and enhance connectivity with other regions of the country, thereby contributing to the strengthening of economic development among the regions in Sri Lanka. The Outer Circular Highway (OCH) is located at the Colombo Metropolitan Region and passes through two administrative districts, namely Colombo and Gampaha. 
The OCH Project consists of three main sections: Phase I runs from Kottawa to Kaduwela (11.0 km) (Phase I); Phase II runs from Kaduwela to Kadawatha (8.9 km); and Phase III runs from Kadawatha to Kerawalapitiya (9.32 km). Metallurgical Corporation of China Ltd (MCC) is the contractor responsible for project implementation. The project commenced on August 20, 2014. Its originally anticipated completion date was June 30, 2019. However, this project faced delays due to poor contractor performance, several houses refusing to vacate, and land acquisition problems at Kadawatha IC due to trade union activities in the survey department.. This project was ultimately completed on November 7, 2019.
Phase III of the Outer Circular Highway Project involves the construction of a 9.32 km segment of the Outer Circular Highway that runs from Kadawatha to Kerawalapitiya. A detailed map of the route of Phase III of the OCH Project is available within Annexure - 05 of the following document: https://mohsl.gov.lk/downloads/1565995085.pdf. Also see https://www.dropbox.com/s/swhrrykgq6tlrtn/sri_lanka_expressway_network_as_at_2019_11_07.jpg?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/1xyhrb7b2jh320w/Sri%20Lanka%20National%20Road%20Network_as-at_2019.jpg?dl=0.
Staff Note: This Project is also known as the Outer Circular Highway Project - Phase III (Kadawatha to Kerwalapitiya). The Chinese project title is 斯里兰卡科伦坡外环高速公路.

title: Chinese government provides $60 million grant to Sri Lanka for low-income housing through ETCA
description:
On May 16, 2017, the Chinese Government and the Government of Sri Lanka signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ECTA) that committed $60 million in grant funding for the development of 2,000 low income housing units.
 In August 2019, Sri Lanka’s Cabinet of Ministers identified the areas where these housing units will be constructed: The Divisional Secretariat Divisions of Moratuwa, Peliagoda, Thimbirigasyaya and Maharagama and land areas in Peliyagoda and Maharagama. However, as of late 2019, this project had still not yet entered implementation. 
 In April 9, 2018, Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) for this project was signed. The Urban Development Authority (UDA) would allocate lands for the construction of these houses.
 STAFF_NOTE: Additional information about the ETCA specifically could not be found.
sources: http://lk.chineseembassy.org/eng/xwdt/t1470918.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/index.php?option=com_rmobilization&view=resource_project&category_id=1&sub_category_id=1&searchby=donor_type&donor_id=4&today=2018-10-23&Itemid=321&lang=en, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/9fuzzplikl2gkpa/housing%20development%20for%20low%20income%20groups%20%282000%20units%29.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://english.utvnews.lk/156473/ , Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.dropbox.com/s/ekfp1xme8y9yz7j/Construction%20of%202000%20housing%20units%20under%20the%20Chinese%20Aid%20Programme%20for%20the%20low%20income%20people.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.dailymirror.lk/breaking_news/China-to-construct-2000-houses-for-low-income-families-in-Colombo/108-165169, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.erd.gov.lk/index.php?option=com_rmobilization&view=resource_project&category_id=2&sub_category_id=3&searchby=donor_type&donor_id=43&today=2019-10-17&Itemid=323&lang=en , Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

name: Biyagama

title: China provided an RMB 48 million grant to Sri Lanka for the Signalization of Welikada Intersection and Improvement of Colombo-Kandy Road Section from Kiribathgoda to Kadawatha Project
description:
On December 18, 2007, Sri Lanka’s Road Development Authority (RDA) signed two contracts with Shanxi Construction Engineering (Group) Corporation (CSCE): one contract worth RMB 45 million for improvement of 2.3 km from Kiribathgoda to Kadawatha of Colombo-Kandy road and for and another contract worth RMB 3 million for the signalization of Welikada Intersection. Both of these contracts were supported by grant assistance from the Chinese Government. 
 Third Railway Survey and Design Institute of China (renamed as China Railway Design Corporation (CRDC) ) was responsible for the design of the road. CSCE was responsible for construction of the road. Through this project, a 2.3 km road segment from Gala Junction Bridge at Kiribathgoda to Kadawatha of Colombo Kandy Road (A001) was widened to four lanes with a 1.2 m centre median, a 1.4 m hard shoulder and a 1.6 m soft shoulder both sides. The project was completed on July 12, 2011.
sources: http://www.parliament.lk/uploads/documents/paperspresented/annual_report_road_development_authority_2011.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.parliament.lk/papers_presented/21092012/annual_report_ministry_of_ports_aviation_2010.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.hovael.com/2018/05/15/highway-project-to-aid-sri-lanka-road-improvement-engineering-for-section-from-kiribathgoda-to-kadawatha-from-colombo-to-kandy-2-3km-china-beijing-international-pvt-ltd-kopiyawatte-road-colombo/, Media Report, including Wikileaks

name: Biyagama

title: China Development Bank provides $195 million loan for Gampaha, Attanagalla, and Miniwangoda Integrated Water Supply Project
description:
In February 2016, China Development Bank (CDB) signed a $195,075,000 million loan agreement for the Gampaha, Attanagalla, and Miniwangoda Integrated Water Supply Project (Gampaha, Attanagalla and Minuwangoda Integrated Water Supply Scheme). This loan carries the following terms: 15 year maturity, 3 year grace period, interest rate of 6-month LIBOR + a 2.95 margin interest rate, and commitment fee of 0.5%. Given that the 6M LIBOR rate in February 2016 was 0.371 %, the total interest rate amounted to 3.321%. The total cost of the project is $229.49 million. China Development Bank (CDB) agreed to cover 85% of the cost. while the remaining 15 percent was borrowed from Bank of Ceylon. 
 The goal of the project is to provide safe and reliable drinking water to the areas of the Gampaha, Minuwangoda and Attanagalla Divisional Secretariat (DS) divisions and part of Meerigama Divisional Secretariat (DS) division. The project is expected to take three years, and will include the construction of Basnagoda 3.5 MCM capacity impounding reservoir at Karasnagala, the construction of 85,000 m3/day capacity water intake at Karasnagala, the construction of 54,000 m3/day capacity Water Treatment Plant (WTP) at Karasnagala, the construction of a waste water and sludge treatment facility including all accessories and pumping equipment at the treatment plant premises, the construction of 10,000 m3 capacity High Level Reservoir (HLR) at Nikahetikanda, construction of five 1,500 m3 capacity elevated water towers at Ranpokunugama, Belummahara, Naiwala, Minuwangoda and Pasyala, the supply and laying of 1,000 mm diameter Ductile Iron (DI) pipes for raw water pumping main of 1.75 km length approximately from the water intake to the WTP, the supply and laying of 1,000 mm dia. DI pipes for treated water pumping main of 1.65 km length approximately from the WTP to the high level reservoir (HLR), the supply and laying of 1,100 mm dia. to 150mm dia. range DI pipes for the gravity transmission main approximate length of 89.2 km from the HLR to existing and new water towers, supply and laying of 225 mm dia. to 90 mm dia. range uPVC pipes for the distribution network, approximate length of 600 km, supply and laying of 400 mm dia. to 300 mm dia. range DI pipes for balance part of the distribution network, approximate length of 30 km, and finally catchment protection. 
The contractor responsible for project implementation is China Machinery Engineering Corporation (CMEC). A groundbreaking ceremony for the project took place on December 5, 2014 (prior to loan approval). As of January 31 2018, the Sri Lankan Department of Project Management and Monitoring reported that the project had achieved a “physical progress” rate of 20.27%. 
This project has been plagued by controversy. In May 2018, former President Chandrika Bandaranaike Kumaratunga demanded that this project be suspended and investigated on the grounds that it was overpriced. The decision to grant a $229.5 million contract to the China Machinery Engineering Corporation (CMEC) in 2012 was based on an unsolicited proposal from the firm. Even while the Rajapaksa administration was still in power, a Cabinet appointed procurement committee noticed a major difference between the cost estimated by the NWSDB engineers for pipe laying and other activities and the higher prices estimated by CMEC. However, a review committee set up after the 2015 change of government recommended continuation of the CMEC project. 
The Auditor General’s (AG) Department also raised concerns about the qualifications of CMEC to undertake such a major project. It noted that the company’s portfolio showed no specialization in water supply projects, and that in the experience section of CMEC’s project proposal it listed the experience of several other companies (China National Machinery Import and Export Cooperation and Tiagin Water Industry Engineering and Equipment Co. Ltd.). 
The AG Department also highlighted that even though government procurement guidelines state that only a maximum of 20 percent can be paid as an advance to a contractor, an advance payment of 34 percent was made to CMEC. Then, in a letter dated May 17, 2018 to the Secretary of the Treasury, Dr. R.H.S. Samaratunge, the Attorney General recommended that a complaint be filed at the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery and Corruption (CIABOC) since it appeared that the project was mired in graft.

title: China Development Bank provides $195 million loan for Gampaha, Attanagalla, and Miniwangoda Integrated Water Supply Project
description:
In February 2016, China Development Bank (CDB) signed a $195,075,000 million loan agreement for the Gampaha, Attanagalla, and Miniwangoda Integrated Water Supply Project (Gampaha, Attanagalla and Minuwangoda Integrated Water Supply Scheme). This loan carries the following terms: 15 year maturity, 3 year grace period, interest rate of 6-month LIBOR + a 2.95 margin interest rate, and commitment fee of 0.5%. Given that the 6M LIBOR rate in February 2016 was 0.371 %, the total interest rate amounted to 3.321%. The total cost of the project is $229.49 million. China Development Bank (CDB) agreed to cover 85% of the cost. while the remaining 15 percent was borrowed from Bank of Ceylon. 
 The goal of the project is to provide safe and reliable drinking water to the areas of the Gampaha, Minuwangoda and Attanagalla Divisional Secretariat (DS) divisions and part of Meerigama Divisional Secretariat (DS) division. The project is expected to take three years, and will include the construction of Basnagoda 3.5 MCM capacity impounding reservoir at Karasnagala, the construction of 85,000 m3/day capacity water intake at Karasnagala, the construction of 54,000 m3/day capacity Water Treatment Plant (WTP) at Karasnagala, the construction of a waste water and sludge treatment facility including all accessories and pumping equipment at the treatment plant premises, the construction of 10,000 m3 capacity High Level Reservoir (HLR) at Nikahetikanda, construction of five 1,500 m3 capacity elevated water towers at Ranpokunugama, Belummahara, Naiwala, Minuwangoda and Pasyala, the supply and laying of 1,000 mm diameter Ductile Iron (DI) pipes for raw water pumping main of 1.75 km length approximately from the water intake to the WTP, the supply and laying of 1,000 mm dia. DI pipes for treated water pumping main of 1.65 km length approximately from the WTP to the high level reservoir (HLR), the supply and laying of 1,100 mm dia. to 150mm dia. range DI pipes for the gravity transmission main approximate length of 89.2 km from the HLR to existing and new water towers, supply and laying of 225 mm dia. to 90 mm dia. range uPVC pipes for the distribution network, approximate length of 600 km, supply and laying of 400 mm dia. to 300 mm dia. range DI pipes for balance part of the distribution network, approximate length of 30 km, and finally catchment protection. 
The contractor responsible for project implementation is China Machinery Engineering Corporation (CMEC). A groundbreaking ceremony for the project took place on December 5, 2014 (prior to loan approval). As of January 31 2018, the Sri Lankan Department of Project Management and Monitoring reported that the project had achieved a “physical progress” rate of 20.27%. 
This project has been plagued by controversy. In May 2018, former President Chandrika Bandaranaike Kumaratunga demanded that this project be suspended and investigated on the grounds that it was overpriced. The decision to grant a $229.5 million contract to the China Machinery Engineering Corporation (CMEC) in 2012 was based on an unsolicited proposal from the firm. Even while the Rajapaksa administration was still in power, a Cabinet appointed procurement committee noticed a major difference between the cost estimated by the NWSDB engineers for pipe laying and other activities and the higher prices estimated by CMEC. However, a review committee set up after the 2015 change of government recommended continuation of the CMEC project. 
The Auditor General’s (AG) Department also raised concerns about the qualifications of CMEC to undertake such a major project. It noted that the company’s portfolio showed no specialization in water supply projects, and that in the experience section of CMEC’s project proposal it listed the experience of several other companies (China National Machinery Import and Export Cooperation and Tiagin Water Industry Engineering and Equipment Co. Ltd.). 
The AG Department also highlighted that even though government procurement guidelines state that only a maximum of 20 percent can be paid as an advance to a contractor, an advance payment of 34 percent was made to CMEC. Then, in a letter dated May 17, 2018 to the Secretary of the Treasury, Dr. R.H.S. Samaratunge, the Attorney General recommended that a complaint be filed at the Commission to Investigate Allegations of Bribery and Corruption (CIABOC) since it appeared that the project was mired in graft.

title: China Eximbank provides $48.3 million buyer’s credit loan for Northern Road Rehabilitation Project (C2) (Linked to Project ID#71641, #71642, #71643, #71644, #71646, #71647)
description:
On April 29, 2011, China Eximbank and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $48.3 million buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreement [No. BLA 201111] for the Northern Road Rehabilitation Project (C2). This BCL carries the following terms: 6-month LIBOR plus a 2% margin, 15-year maturity, 3-year grace period, 0.5% management fee, 0.7% commitment fee, and a 6% exposure fee. The average 6 Month LIBOR rate in April 2011 was 0.442%. Total interest rate is therefore coded as 0.442% + 2.0%, or 2.442%. 
 The purpose of the Northern Road Rehabilitation Project (C2) was to rehabilitate the 67 km Navatkuli-Karaitivu-Mannar (A032) Road. C2 stands for Contract 2. China Harbour Engineering Corporation was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The preliminary works of the project commenced on November 10, 2011. The project was originally slated for completion by May 9, 2014. The activities of the project had been “substantially completed” by May 12, 2014 and handed over to Sri Lanka’s Road Development Authority. However, the project was not fully and officially complete until December 31, 2014. 
 STAFF_NOTE: This project is also known as Rehabilitation & Improvement of 67km Length of Navatkuli-Karaitivu-Mannar Road Project and the 67Km Length of Navatkuli-Karaitivu-Mannar Road (A032) - C2 Project. The Chinese project title is 北部道路改造与基建恢复项目. Some official sources identify the management fee as 0.3%.

name: Nanaddan

title: Chinese Government provides $18.2 million grant for post-tsunami reconstruction of Panadura, Beruwela and Kudawela fishing harbors
description:
On February 21, 2005, Chinese Government and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $18,207,786 grant agreement for the post-tsunami reconstruction of fishing harbors in Panadura, Beruwela and Kudawela (on the country’s western and southern coasts). 
 China Harbour Engineering Company was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began in 2005, and the project was completed on December 28, 2007. 
 STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese Government reportedly contributed $63 million in total for tsunami relief projects. Most of the individual projects that the Chinese Government financed are captured in AidData’s dataset and linked to Project ID #41811.

title: China Eximbank provides $494.03 preferential buyer’s credit for Phase III of the Outer Circular Highway Project (Kadawatha to Kerawalapitiya Section)
description:
On September 16, 2014, China Eximbank and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $494.03 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) agreement [No.PBC(2014) 15 Total No.(309)] for Phase III of the Outer Circular Highway Project (Kadawatha to Kerawalapitiya Section). This PBC carries the following terms: 2% interest rate. 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, 0.25% commitment fee, and a 0.25% management fee. 
The objective of the purpose of the project is to construct an expressway in the outskirts of Colombo which connects with the Southern Expressway and other national roads radiating from Colombo city in order to mitigate traffic congestion in the Colombo Metropolitan Region and enhance connectivity with other regions of the country, thereby contributing to the strengthening of economic development among the regions in Sri Lanka. The Outer Circular Highway (OCH) is located at the Colombo Metropolitan Region and passes through two administrative districts, namely Colombo and Gampaha. 
The OCH Project consists of three main sections: Phase I runs from Kottawa to Kaduwela (11.0 km) (Phase I); Phase II runs from Kaduwela to Kadawatha (8.9 km); and Phase III runs from Kadawatha to Kerawalapitiya (9.32 km). Metallurgical Corporation of China Ltd (MCC) is the contractor responsible for project implementation. The project commenced on August 20, 2014. Its originally anticipated completion date was June 30, 2019. However, this project faced delays due to poor contractor performance, several houses refusing to vacate, and land acquisition problems at Kadawatha IC due to trade union activities in the survey department.. This project was ultimately completed on November 7, 2019.
Phase III of the Outer Circular Highway Project involves the construction of a 9.32 km segment of the Outer Circular Highway that runs from Kadawatha to Kerawalapitiya. A detailed map of the route of Phase III of the OCH Project is available within Annexure - 05 of the following document: https://mohsl.gov.lk/downloads/1565995085.pdf. Also see https://www.dropbox.com/s/swhrrykgq6tlrtn/sri_lanka_expressway_network_as_at_2019_11_07.jpg?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/1xyhrb7b2jh320w/Sri%20Lanka%20National%20Road%20Network_as-at_2019.jpg?dl=0.
Staff Note: This Project is also known as the Outer Circular Highway Project - Phase III (Kadawatha to Kerwalapitiya). The Chinese project title is 斯里兰卡科伦坡外环高速公路.
