title: CDB provides $500 million loan for Rehabilitation and Improvement of Priority Road Project 2 (PRP2) (Linked to Project ID #46971, #33402 and #39002)
description: On March 31, 2011, China Development Bank and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $500 million loan facility agreement (No. 4500062212011110472) for the Rehabilitation and Improvement of Priority Road Project 2 (PRP2). This loan carries the following terms: 15 year maturity, 4 year grace period, interest rate of 6-month LIBOR pus a 2.9% margin, 0.5% management fee, 3.26% risk (insurance) premium. The first tranche of escrow funding (worth $326 million) was received by the Central Bank of Sri Lanka on June 29, 2011 and second tranche of escrow funding (worth $174 million) was on 28th October 28, 2011. The total cost of the PRP2 was $556 million. 90% of the project cost was covered by CDB and approximately 10% of the project cost was provided by the Government of Sri Lanka. The purpose of the project to rehabilitate and improve 581 km in 20 roads, including 95 km of provincial roads in Nuwara Eliya district, construction of two flyovers and reconstruction and widening of 22 bridges under two components (see Development Performance Report Year End Review 2015 from the Sri Lanka Department of Project Management). The 24 project components listed below include the 20 road sections, the 2 flyovers, and the 2 bridge components. This project included 24 components: 1. Horawela-Pelawatte-Pitigala Road: 0.0 - 17.50 km 2. Horana-Anguruwatota-Aluthgama Road: 5.0 - 32.0 km (total length of 27.0 km) 3. Horawela-Pelawatta-Pitigala Road: 17.5 - 25.74 km (total length of 8.24 km) 4. Construction of a flyover at Mattala airport access road junction in Hambantota Hub Development. 5. Construction of a flyover at 100 feet road and bypass road junction in Hambantota Hub Development. 6. Reconstruction/widening of Bridges on Tiruwanaketiya-Agalawatta Road: 33.45 - 67.80 km (total length of 34.35 km) 7. Reconstruction/widening of Bridges on Horana-Anguruwayoya-Aluthgama Road: 5.0 - 32.0 km (total length of 27.0 km) 8. Thihagoda-Kamburupitiya-Mawarala-Kotapola Road: 23.0 - 67.0 km (total length of 44.0 km) 9. Hungama-Middeniya Road: 0.0 - 30.0 km 10. Nagoda-Kalawellawa-Bellapitiya Road: 27.0 - 57.0 km (total length of 30.0 km) This project included the following components in the Northern Zone (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 'Resource Mobilization'): 11. Kandy-Mahiyangana-Padiyathalawa Road: 93.15 - 102.28 km (total length of 9.13 km) 12. Badulla-Karamatiya-Andaulpotha Road: 0.0 - 48 km 13. Mahiyangana-Dimbulagala-Daukkane Road: 0.0 - 24.10 km 14. Bibile-Uraniya-Mahiyangana Road: 22.0 - 39.58 km (total length of 17.58 km) 15. Galkulama-Anuradhapura Road: 0.0 - 15.0 km & 16.0 - 16.64 km (total length of 15.64 km) 16. Kadahapoka-Rambawewa Road: 0.0 - 18.71 km 17. Kurunegala-Narammala-Madampe Road: 0.0 - 22.36 km 18. Galagedara-Rambukkana Road: 0.0 - 18.5 km 19. Tennekumbura-Rikillagaskada-Ragala Road: 20.2 - 73.64 km (total length of 53.44 km) 20. Uswetakeiyawa-Epamulla-Pamunugama Road: 0.0 - 8.05 km 21. Palaviya-Kalpitiya Road: 14.0 - 40.60 km (total length of 26.60 km) 22. Mahiyangana-Dimbulagala-Dalukkane Road: 24.10 - 72.8 km (total length of 48.7 km) 23. Manampitiya-Aralaganwila-Maduru Oya Road: 0.0 - 3.0 km 24. Provincial Roads in Nuwaraeliya District: 85.01 km. Xi'an Dagang Road Machinery Co. Ltd., China National Aero Technology International Engineering Corporation, and Hunan Construction Engineering Corporation were the three contractors responsible for project implementation. Implementation PRP2 began on June 28, 2011 and it was completed on December 31, 2014. Staff Note: The interest rate is coded based on 6-month LIBOR at time of signing of the loan agreement. The average 6-month LIBOR rate in March 2011 was 0.461%. The total interest rate is therefore coded as 0.461% + 2.90%, or 3.361%. The Priority Road Project had three phases; see Project ID #46971 (PRP1), Project ID #33402 (PRP3-Phase 1), and Project ID #39002 (PRP3-Phase 2) for more details.

title: CDB provides $500 million loan for Rehabilitation and Improvement of Priority Road Project 2 (PRP2) (Linked to Project ID #46971, #33402 and #39002)
description: On March 31, 2011, China Development Bank and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $500 million loan facility agreement (No. 4500062212011110472) for the Rehabilitation and Improvement of Priority Road Project 2 (PRP2). This loan carries the following terms: 15 year maturity, 4 year grace period, interest rate of 6-month LIBOR pus a 2.9% margin, 0.5% management fee, 3.26% risk (insurance) premium. The first tranche of escrow funding (worth $326 million) was received by the Central Bank of Sri Lanka on June 29, 2011 and second tranche of escrow funding (worth $174 million) was on 28th October 28, 2011. The total cost of the PRP2 was $556 million. 90% of the project cost was covered by CDB and approximately 10% of the project cost was provided by the Government of Sri Lanka. The purpose of the project to rehabilitate and improve 581 km in 20 roads, including 95 km of provincial roads in Nuwara Eliya district, construction of two flyovers and reconstruction and widening of 22 bridges under two components (see Development Performance Report Year End Review 2015 from the Sri Lanka Department of Project Management). The 24 project components listed below include the 20 road sections, the 2 flyovers, and the 2 bridge components. This project included 24 components: 1. Horawela-Pelawatte-Pitigala Road: 0.0 - 17.50 km 2. Horana-Anguruwatota-Aluthgama Road: 5.0 - 32.0 km (total length of 27.0 km) 3. Horawela-Pelawatta-Pitigala Road: 17.5 - 25.74 km (total length of 8.24 km) 4. Construction of a flyover at Mattala airport access road junction in Hambantota Hub Development. 5. Construction of a flyover at 100 feet road and bypass road junction in Hambantota Hub Development. 6. Reconstruction/widening of Bridges on Tiruwanaketiya-Agalawatta Road: 33.45 - 67.80 km (total length of 34.35 km) 7. Reconstruction/widening of Bridges on Horana-Anguruwayoya-Aluthgama Road: 5.0 - 32.0 km (total length of 27.0 km) 8. Thihagoda-Kamburupitiya-Mawarala-Kotapola Road: 23.0 - 67.0 km (total length of 44.0 km) 9. Hungama-Middeniya Road: 0.0 - 30.0 km 10. Nagoda-Kalawellawa-Bellapitiya Road: 27.0 - 57.0 km (total length of 30.0 km) This project included the following components in the Northern Zone (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 'Resource Mobilization'): 11. Kandy-Mahiyangana-Padiyathalawa Road: 93.15 - 102.28 km (total length of 9.13 km) 12. Badulla-Karamatiya-Andaulpotha Road: 0.0 - 48 km 13. Mahiyangana-Dimbulagala-Daukkane Road: 0.0 - 24.10 km 14. Bibile-Uraniya-Mahiyangana Road: 22.0 - 39.58 km (total length of 17.58 km) 15. Galkulama-Anuradhapura Road: 0.0 - 15.0 km & 16.0 - 16.64 km (total length of 15.64 km) 16. Kadahapoka-Rambawewa Road: 0.0 - 18.71 km 17. Kurunegala-Narammala-Madampe Road: 0.0 - 22.36 km 18. Galagedara-Rambukkana Road: 0.0 - 18.5 km 19. Tennekumbura-Rikillagaskada-Ragala Road: 20.2 - 73.64 km (total length of 53.44 km) 20. Uswetakeiyawa-Epamulla-Pamunugama Road: 0.0 - 8.05 km 21. Palaviya-Kalpitiya Road: 14.0 - 40.60 km (total length of 26.60 km) 22. Mahiyangana-Dimbulagala-Dalukkane Road: 24.10 - 72.8 km (total length of 48.7 km) 23. Manampitiya-Aralaganwila-Maduru Oya Road: 0.0 - 3.0 km 24. Provincial Roads in Nuwaraeliya District: 85.01 km. Xi'an Dagang Road Machinery Co. Ltd., China National Aero Technology International Engineering Corporation, and Hunan Construction Engineering Corporation were the three contractors responsible for project implementation. Implementation PRP2 began on June 28, 2011 and it was completed on December 31, 2014. Staff Note: The interest rate is coded based on 6-month LIBOR at time of signing of the loan agreement. The average 6-month LIBOR rate in March 2011 was 0.461%. The total interest rate is therefore coded as 0.461% + 2.90%, or 3.361%. The Priority Road Project had three phases; see Project ID #46971 (PRP1), Project ID #33402 (PRP3-Phase 1), and Project ID #39002 (PRP3-Phase 2) for more details.

name: Lunugamvehera

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 1.3 billion government concessional loan for the Mattala Rajapaksa International Airport Project
description:
On December 23, 2009, China Eximbank and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a government concessional loan (GCL) agreement worth RMB 1.3 billion for the Mattala Rajapaksa International Airport Project. The GCL carried the following terms: 2% interest rate, 20-year maturity, 5-year grace period, commitment fee of 0.5%, and management fee of 0.5%. The purpose of the $209 million project was to construct an alternative airport, located in Mattala, to the Bandaranaike international Airport. 
China Harbour Engineering Company was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The project involved the construction of a 4 km runway, a parking apron, a taxiway connecting the runaway and the apron, a terminal building, cargo storage, a fuel arm, and a fire service building. Construction began on November 17, 2009. The construction of the runway, apron and taxiways was completed ahead of schedule in February 2012. On January 24, 2013, Sri Lanka’s Minister of Civil Aviation Piyankara Jayaratne reported to parliament that the airport would be declared open on March 18, 2013. On October 16, 2012, a Hawker Beechcraft B200 King Air of the Pakistan Civil Aviation Authority became the first aircraft to land at the new airport. The airport was opened for flight operations, as planned, on March 18, 2013. President Rajapaksa, his ministers, and other dignitaries arrived in a SriLankan Airlines Airbus A340 to attend the inauguration ceremony. 
This project was plagued by cost overruns and controversy. It ultimately cost $243.7 million to implement the project. However, the original budget for the project was $209 million. The Mattala Rajapaksa International Airport is also widely considered to be a commercial failure. The construction of the 12,000 square meter terminal building was originally designed to support as many as one million travelers per year, and the government envisioned major international carriers bringing travelers from Beijing, Chennai, Dubai, Riyadh, and Bangkok to Hambantota for sporting events, international conferences, eco-tourism, and nightlife. However, it was eventually dubbed “the world’s emptiest international airport.” 
Sri Lanka’s aviation minister reported to parliament in 2014 that the airport had only earned $123 in revenue in a single month, and when a visiting journalist asked a senior government official about the airport, he indicated, “when I visited the airport there, I asked the sole immigration officer how many passports she’d stamped that day. She said, ‘One’.” Within only a few years of becoming fully operational, the airport was running an annual financial loss of $18 million. Consequently, the airport failed to generate sufficient revenue to facilitate loan repayment. in January 2015, Maithripala Sirisena was elected President of Sri Lanka and one of his first orders was to allow SriLankan Airlines to cancel all flights to Mattala Rajapaksa International Airport. The national carrier released a public statement that read: “[T]he reality is Mattala Rajapaksa International Airport is not needed and is a distraction in Sri Lankan’s efforts to turn itself around. … SriLankan Airlines continues to be highly unprofitable and having to meet the political requirement of developing and operating a second hub [in Hambantota district] will make it even harder to meet its targets for financial improvement.” 
Mattala Rajapaksa International Airport Project is located in the town of Mattala, 18 km (11 mi) from Hambantota. Additional locational information can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Mattala+Rajapaksa+Hambantota+Airport/@6.2929635,81.1239019,15z/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x0:0x4f504dac455a700c?sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwiymbiF1dbpAhXClXIEHS6dCcsQ_BIwE3oECBcQCA.
STAFF_NOTE: Some reports suggest that the face value of the China Eximbank GCL was $209 million. However, this figure refers to the total cost of the project (prior to cost overruns). In correspondence with AidData’s Executive Director, the Director of the China and AIIB Division with the External Resources Department of Ministry of National Policies and Economic Affairs confirmed that USD loan value of the RMB-denominated China Eximbank loan is approximately $190 million. Note that the Mattala Rajapaksa International Airport is also known as the Mattala Hambantota International Airport Project, Hambantota International Airport, and Southern International Airport).

title: CDB provides $500 million loan for Rehabilitation and Improvement of Priority Road Project 2 (PRP2) (Linked to Project ID #46971, #33402 and #39002)
description: On March 31, 2011, China Development Bank and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $500 million loan facility agreement (No. 4500062212011110472) for the Rehabilitation and Improvement of Priority Road Project 2 (PRP2). This loan carries the following terms: 15 year maturity, 4 year grace period, interest rate of 6-month LIBOR pus a 2.9% margin, 0.5% management fee, 3.26% risk (insurance) premium. The first tranche of escrow funding (worth $326 million) was received by the Central Bank of Sri Lanka on June 29, 2011 and second tranche of escrow funding (worth $174 million) was on 28th October 28, 2011. The total cost of the PRP2 was $556 million. 90% of the project cost was covered by CDB and approximately 10% of the project cost was provided by the Government of Sri Lanka. The purpose of the project to rehabilitate and improve 581 km in 20 roads, including 95 km of provincial roads in Nuwara Eliya district, construction of two flyovers and reconstruction and widening of 22 bridges under two components (see Development Performance Report Year End Review 2015 from the Sri Lanka Department of Project Management). The 24 project components listed below include the 20 road sections, the 2 flyovers, and the 2 bridge components. This project included 24 components: 1. Horawela-Pelawatte-Pitigala Road: 0.0 - 17.50 km 2. Horana-Anguruwatota-Aluthgama Road: 5.0 - 32.0 km (total length of 27.0 km) 3. Horawela-Pelawatta-Pitigala Road: 17.5 - 25.74 km (total length of 8.24 km) 4. Construction of a flyover at Mattala airport access road junction in Hambantota Hub Development. 5. Construction of a flyover at 100 feet road and bypass road junction in Hambantota Hub Development. 6. Reconstruction/widening of Bridges on Tiruwanaketiya-Agalawatta Road: 33.45 - 67.80 km (total length of 34.35 km) 7. Reconstruction/widening of Bridges on Horana-Anguruwayoya-Aluthgama Road: 5.0 - 32.0 km (total length of 27.0 km) 8. Thihagoda-Kamburupitiya-Mawarala-Kotapola Road: 23.0 - 67.0 km (total length of 44.0 km) 9. Hungama-Middeniya Road: 0.0 - 30.0 km 10. Nagoda-Kalawellawa-Bellapitiya Road: 27.0 - 57.0 km (total length of 30.0 km) This project included the following components in the Northern Zone (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 'Resource Mobilization'): 11. Kandy-Mahiyangana-Padiyathalawa Road: 93.15 - 102.28 km (total length of 9.13 km) 12. Badulla-Karamatiya-Andaulpotha Road: 0.0 - 48 km 13. Mahiyangana-Dimbulagala-Daukkane Road: 0.0 - 24.10 km 14. Bibile-Uraniya-Mahiyangana Road: 22.0 - 39.58 km (total length of 17.58 km) 15. Galkulama-Anuradhapura Road: 0.0 - 15.0 km & 16.0 - 16.64 km (total length of 15.64 km) 16. Kadahapoka-Rambawewa Road: 0.0 - 18.71 km 17. Kurunegala-Narammala-Madampe Road: 0.0 - 22.36 km 18. Galagedara-Rambukkana Road: 0.0 - 18.5 km 19. Tennekumbura-Rikillagaskada-Ragala Road: 20.2 - 73.64 km (total length of 53.44 km) 20. Uswetakeiyawa-Epamulla-Pamunugama Road: 0.0 - 8.05 km 21. Palaviya-Kalpitiya Road: 14.0 - 40.60 km (total length of 26.60 km) 22. Mahiyangana-Dimbulagala-Dalukkane Road: 24.10 - 72.8 km (total length of 48.7 km) 23. Manampitiya-Aralaganwila-Maduru Oya Road: 0.0 - 3.0 km 24. Provincial Roads in Nuwaraeliya District: 85.01 km. Xi'an Dagang Road Machinery Co. Ltd., China National Aero Technology International Engineering Corporation, and Hunan Construction Engineering Corporation were the three contractors responsible for project implementation. Implementation PRP2 began on June 28, 2011 and it was completed on December 31, 2014. Staff Note: The interest rate is coded based on 6-month LIBOR at time of signing of the loan agreement. The average 6-month LIBOR rate in March 2011 was 0.461%. The total interest rate is therefore coded as 0.461% + 2.90%, or 3.361%. The Priority Road Project had three phases; see Project ID #46971 (PRP1), Project ID #33402 (PRP3-Phase 1), and Project ID #39002 (PRP3-Phase 2) for more details.

title: CDB provides $152.8 million loan for Rehabilitation and Improvement of Priority Road Project 1 (PRP1) (Linked to Project ID #39001, #33402 and #39002)
description:
On December 16, 2010, China Development Bank and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $152.8 million loan agreement (No. 4500402212010110492) for the Priority Road Project-1 (PRP1). This loan carries the following terms: 15 year maturity, 3 year grace period, an interest rather of 6-month LIBOR plus a 2.9% margin, a 0.5% management fee, and a 5% risk (insurance) premium. The 6-month LIBOR rate for 2010 was 1.098%, so the interest rate for this loan totaled 3.998% once the margin was included. 
The total project cost was US$169.8 million, it is unclear which organization provided the remaining funding. The purpose of the project was to provide an efficient national road network that would lower transportation costs and improve the integration of the country. The project sought to construct or rehabilitate 9 different road segments: (1) the 7.47 km Beliatta Tangalle Road on the C1A; (2) the Bopale - Kiribbanara - Uadamauara Road on the C12A; (3) the Flyover at Siribopura Junction on the C1A; (4) the 47 km Pelawatta Kankotiyawatta Thiniyawala Morawaka Road on the C2A; (5) the 0 - 033.45 km Thiruwanaketiya Agalawatta Road on the C3; (6) the 20.5 km Kandy - Mahiyangana- Padiyathalawa Road on the C6A; (7) the 5.63 km Kalkudah Road on the C8; (8) the 4.42km Kalkudah Valachchenai Road on the C8; and (9) the 52 km Paranthan Mullaitivu Road on the C11. 
China National Aero Technology International Engineering Corporation (CATIC-ENG) is the contractor responsible for project implementation. Its work was overseen by the Government of Sri Lanka’s Road Development Authority. Project implementation began on December 29, 2010 and was originally scheduled for completion by December 29, 2014. However, the project did not reach completion until December 31, 2015. 
The Priority Road Project had three phases; see Project ID #39001 (PRP2), Project #33402 (PRP3-Phase 1), and Project #39002 (PRP3-Phase 2) for more details.

title: CDB provides $152.8 million loan for Rehabilitation and Improvement of Priority Road Project 1 (PRP1) (Linked to Project ID #39001, #33402 and #39002)
description:
On December 16, 2010, China Development Bank and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $152.8 million loan agreement (No. 4500402212010110492) for the Priority Road Project-1 (PRP1). This loan carries the following terms: 15 year maturity, 3 year grace period, an interest rather of 6-month LIBOR plus a 2.9% margin, a 0.5% management fee, and a 5% risk (insurance) premium. The 6-month LIBOR rate for 2010 was 1.098%, so the interest rate for this loan totaled 3.998% once the margin was included. 
The total project cost was US$169.8 million, it is unclear which organization provided the remaining funding. The purpose of the project was to provide an efficient national road network that would lower transportation costs and improve the integration of the country. The project sought to construct or rehabilitate 9 different road segments: (1) the 7.47 km Beliatta Tangalle Road on the C1A; (2) the Bopale - Kiribbanara - Uadamauara Road on the C12A; (3) the Flyover at Siribopura Junction on the C1A; (4) the 47 km Pelawatta Kankotiyawatta Thiniyawala Morawaka Road on the C2A; (5) the 0 - 033.45 km Thiruwanaketiya Agalawatta Road on the C3; (6) the 20.5 km Kandy - Mahiyangana- Padiyathalawa Road on the C6A; (7) the 5.63 km Kalkudah Road on the C8; (8) the 4.42km Kalkudah Valachchenai Road on the C8; and (9) the 52 km Paranthan Mullaitivu Road on the C11. 
China National Aero Technology International Engineering Corporation (CATIC-ENG) is the contractor responsible for project implementation. Its work was overseen by the Government of Sri Lanka’s Road Development Authority. Project implementation began on December 29, 2010 and was originally scheduled for completion by December 29, 2014. However, the project did not reach completion until December 31, 2015. 
The Priority Road Project had three phases; see Project ID #39001 (PRP2), Project #33402 (PRP3-Phase 1), and Project #39002 (PRP3-Phase 2) for more details.
sources: http://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/linked-documents/42254-014-sri-dc.pdf, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://www.mohsl.gov.lk/web/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=53&Itemid=60&lang=en, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/files/Parliament%20Question%20-%20Export%20Credit%2022.052014.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/index.php?option=com_rmobilization&view=resource_project&category_id=1&sub_category_id=1&searchby=donor_type&donor_id=4&today=2018-10-23&Itemid=321&lang=en, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/udvlumdle28we4n/Government%20of%20Sri%20Lanka%202017%20Bond%20Prospectus.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://global.factiva.com/du/article.aspx/?accessionno=XNHA000020160406ec4600105&fcpil=en&napc=S&sa_from=&cat=a, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/9my7gk28k6hjf1v/Rehabililitation%20%26%20improvement%20of%20Priority%20Road%20Projects%20-%201.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.auditorgeneral.gov.lk/web/images/audit-reports/Road%20Network%20Improvement%20Priority%20Project%201%20E.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.treasury.gov.lk/documents/10181/12882/2013/99ec4ce9-183d-40ea-abfa-8331cdeee19d?version=1.0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.cbsl.gov.lk/sites/default/files/cbslweb_documents/publications/annual_report/2015/en/14_Part_02.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://web.archive.org/web/20180107040947/http://www.erd.gov.lk/files/Parliament%20Question%20-%20Export%20Credit%2022.052014.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/31zp9c4aoz1cmlt/Priority%20Roads%20Project%20funded%20by%20the%20China%20Development%20Bank%20Company%20Ltd.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: China Development Bank provides $242.66 million loan for Valachchenai Water Supply Project and Banadarawela, Diyathalawa and Haputhale Water Supply Project
description:
In 2017, China Development Bank and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $242.66 million loan agreement for the Valachchenai Water Supply Project and the Bandarawela, Diyathalawa, and Haputhale Water Supply Project. According to the Sri Lanka Department of External Resources Performance Report 2017, this loan covers 100% of the estimated project cost.
This project is expected to be completed in 3 years. The goal of the project is to provide safe drinking water to Bandarawela, Diyathalawa, Haputhale and Valachchenai. China National Aero–Technology International Engineering Corporation (CATIC) and China Geo Engineering Corporation (CHINA GEO ENG) are the contractors responsible for project implementation. Their work is being supervised by the Sri Lanka National Water Supply and Drainage Board. The project officially entered implementation on August 30, 2017. 
Staff Note: This project is one of the four water supply projects under implementation in Sri Lanka funded by the China Development Bank. The other three projects are: Project ID# 54435 (Gampaha, Attanagalla and Minuwangoda Integrated Water Supply Scheme), Project ID# 53566 (Katana Water supply Project), and Project ID# 53567 (Thambuttegama Water Supply Project). In Sri Lanka government documents, the Valachchenai Water Supply Project and Bandarawela, Diyathalawa and Haputhale Water Supply Project are sometimes referred to as 'Balance of 400 million facility for priority Water Supply Projects', because they account for the final allocation of a $400 million CDB loan facility for water supply projects.
sources: http://www.erd.gov.lk/index.php?option=com_rmobilization&view=resource_project&category_id=1&sub_category_id=1&searchby=donor_type&donor_id=4&today=2018-10-23&Itemid=321&lang=en, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/images/Publications/ERDReport2017/ERDReport2017-English.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=97:recently-signed-water-projects-china-division&catid=30&lang=en&Itemid=225, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.waterboard.lk/web/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&id=58&Itemid=272&lang=en, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/wfeccl6aq3hgq42/%20Valachchenai%20Water%20Supply%20Project%20Bandarawela%2C%20Diyathalawa%2C%20Haputhale%20Water%20Supply%20Project.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://web.archive.org/web/20180107040947/http://www.erd.gov.lk/files/Parliament%20Question%20-%20Export%20Credit%2022.052014.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/index.php?option=com_rmobilization&view=resource_project&category_id=1&sub_category_id=1&searchby=donor_type&donor_id=12&today=2019-10-17&Itemid=321&lang=en, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: China donates 2,752 tons of rice to Sri Lanka for drought relief
description: In 2017, China agreed to donate 2,752 tons of rice to Sri Lanka drought victims. In November of 2017, the first 1000 tons of this rice were delivered. The second 1,000 tons was delivered in December 2017. The remaining 752 tons reached Colombo in late December. It was received by the Disaster Management Ministry in Colombo. The drought is considered the worst in 40 years due to delay of monsoonal rains and has affected over 1 million people in 11 districts.
sources: http://www.xinhuanet.com//english/2017-12/11/c_136817807.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.xinhuanet.com//english/2017-12/11/c_136817807.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://gain.fas.usda.gov/Recent%20GAIN%20Publications/Grain%20and%20Feed%20Update_Beijing_China%20-%20Peoples%20Republic%20of_2-1-2018.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)
GEO_notes: The final 752 tons was given to the Disaster Management Ministry which is in Colombo
name: Colombo

title: CICT donated US$150,000 to Pushpa Rajapaksa Foundation
description:
On May 21, 2012, the Colombo International Container Terminals Limited (CICT), which is a joint venture of the China Merchants Port Holdings Company (CMPort) and the Sri Lanka Ports Authority (SLPA) donated $150,000 (Rs.19,410,000) to the Pushpa Rajapaksa Foundation for the construction of houses for the under-privileged as part of the company’s Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR). The donated amount from the Chinese side is unknown, so the transaction amount has been removed.
 
 The donation had been remitted to Pushpa Rajapaksa Foundation by CICT through the Hong Kong and Shanghai Banking Corporation (cheque No. 594691) to the Foundation’s account (No. 204-1-001-5-0003290) maintained at Peoples Bank. It was said that the donation was made long after the project concession agreement for the Colombo South Terminal had been signed and construction work on the terminal had already commenced. The payment is clearly reflected in its audited accounts for the relevant year. However, though the donation was documented as construction costs, some reports suggest that the donation was for Mahinda Rajapaksa’s 2015 re-election campaign.
crs_sector_name: Support to Non-governmental Organizations (NGOs) and Government Organizations
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=SLDAIM0020180716ee7d0000i&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.lankaweb.com/news/items/2018/07/12/rs-19-mn-to-pushpa-rajapaksa-foundation-was-a-donation-cict/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Rs-mn-to-Pushpa-Rajapaksa-Foundation-was-a-donation-CICT-152607.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.dailymirror.lk/article/Questionable-Donation-from-CICT-States-that-the-monies-offered-to-the-Pushpa-Rajapaksa-Foundation-was-done-as-part-of-a-CSR-commitment-152833.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/chinese-company-says-donated-to-rajapaksa-family-foundation-118071201235_1.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://economynext.com/chinese-firm-in-sri-lanka-admits-funding-rajapaksa-family-foundation-10832/, Media Report, including Wikileaks

title: China donates books to Sri Lankan schools
description: Exercise books were donated to Dhamma Schools of Gautama Viharaya at Green Park, Narahenpita, Sri Naga Viharaya Kotte, Royal College Colombo, Thilakerathnaramaya Borella and Sri Seewali Dhamma School of Sri Nagaviharaya at Baseline Road. title: China Eximbank provides $31.6 million buyer’s credit loan for Procurement of Material for the Northern Province Power Sector Development Programme (Uthuru Wasanthaya)
description:
On September 9, 2010, China Eximbank and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $31,659,391.82 buyer’s credit loan (BCL) for the Procurement of Material for the Northern Province Power Sector Development Programme (Uthuru Wasanthaya). The BCL carried the following terms: an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR + a 2.8% margin, 12 year maturity, 2 year grace period, 0.7% commitment fee, and 0.5% management fee. 
 The average 6-month LIBOR rate in September 2010 was 0.478%. The total interest rate is therefore coded as 0.478% + 2.80%, or 3.278%. The proceeds from the BCL were to be used to procure materials for the provision of electricity to 80,000 consumers living in Northern Province by constructing 400 rural electrification schemes. 
 China National Complete Plant Import & Export Corporation (COMPLANT) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Its work was overseen by the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB). According to the Government of Sri Lanka’s External Resources Department (ERD), this project was completed on September 9, 2012. 
 However, this project has been plagued by controversy. A fraud investigation revealed that the contractor provided substantially fewer materials than it was contractually obligated to provide.

title: China Eximbank provides $48.3 million buyer’s credit loan for Northern Road Rehabilitation Project (C2) (Linked to Project ID#71641, #71642, #71643, #71644, #71646, #71647)
description:
On April 29, 2011, China Eximbank and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $48.3 million buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreement [No. BLA 201111] for the Northern Road Rehabilitation Project (C2). This BCL carries the following terms: 6-month LIBOR plus a 2% margin, 15-year maturity, 3-year grace period, 0.5% management fee, 0.7% commitment fee, and a 6% exposure fee. The average 6 Month LIBOR rate in April 2011 was 0.442%. Total interest rate is therefore coded as 0.442% + 2.0%, or 2.442%. 
 The purpose of the Northern Road Rehabilitation Project (C2) was to rehabilitate the 67 km Navatkuli-Karaitivu-Mannar (A032) Road. C2 stands for Contract 2. China Harbour Engineering Corporation was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The preliminary works of the project commenced on November 10, 2011. The project was originally slated for completion by May 9, 2014. The activities of the project had been “substantially completed” by May 12, 2014 and handed over to Sri Lanka’s Road Development Authority. However, the project was not fully and officially complete until December 31, 2014. 
 STAFF_NOTE: This project is also known as Rehabilitation & Improvement of 67km Length of Navatkuli-Karaitivu-Mannar Road Project and the 67Km Length of Navatkuli-Karaitivu-Mannar Road (A032) - C2 Project. The Chinese project title is 北部道路改造与基建恢复项目. Some official sources identify the management fee as 0.3%.

GEO_notes: Coded the Mannar District since A032 runs ends in the Mannar Divisional Secretariat

title: China Eximbank provides $31.6 million buyer’s credit loan for Procurement of Material for the Northern Province Power Sector Development Programme (Uthuru Wasanthaya)
description:
On September 9, 2010, China Eximbank and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $31,659,391.82 buyer’s credit loan (BCL) for the Procurement of Material for the Northern Province Power Sector Development Programme (Uthuru Wasanthaya). The BCL carried the following terms: an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR + a 2.8% margin, 12 year maturity, 2 year grace period, 0.7% commitment fee, and 0.5% management fee. 
 The average 6-month LIBOR rate in September 2010 was 0.478%. The total interest rate is therefore coded as 0.478% + 2.80%, or 3.278%. The proceeds from the BCL were to be used to procure materials for the provision of electricity to 80,000 consumers living in Northern Province by constructing 400 rural electrification schemes. 
 China National Complete Plant Import & Export Corporation (COMPLANT) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Its work was overseen by the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB). According to the Government of Sri Lanka’s External Resources Department (ERD), this project was completed on September 9, 2012. 
 However, this project has been plagued by controversy. A fraud investigation revealed that the contractor provided substantially fewer materials than it was contractually obligated to provide.

title: China donates school supplies to students in village schools in Sri Lanka

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 487 million government concessional loan for Greater Kurunegala Water Supply & Sanitation Project
description:
On September 18, 2013, China Eximbank and the Government of Sri Lanka signed an RMB 487 million government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the Greater Kurunegala Water Supply & Sanitation Project. The GCL carries a 2% fixed interest rate, a 5 year grace period, a maturity of 20 years, a 0.25% management fee, and a 0.25% commitment fee. 
 The objective of the project was to meet the present and future demand of drinking water in the Greater Kurunegala area by increasing water supply capacity from 6500m3/d to 13000m3/d and establishing a proper waste water disposal system with a capacity 0f 4500m3/d. This project involved the construction of a new treatment plant, a pipe sewer network (135 km), water transmission lines(8km), water distribution network (110km), and two elevated water towers (Kurunagala 1750 m3/d, 750 m3/d at Vahara). 
 China Machinery Engineering Corporation (CMEC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation.The project began on February 26, 2014 and was completed on August 13, 2018. Upon completion, the project reportedly covered 397 square kilometers and solved the problem of access to clean drinking water for 600,000 people in 42 villages. 
 STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 斯里兰卡库鲁内格勒供水和污水处理项目. This project is also known as the Greater Kurunegala Water Supply & Sanitation (Sewerage) Project.

title: Provision of Sporting Goods for Youth in Jaffna, Kilinochchi and Mullaitivu
description: On 4 May 2012, the Chinese government signed a 1 million CNY grant agreement with Sri Lanka for the provision of sporting goods for the youth in Jaffna, Kilinochchi and Mullaitivu (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 2012 Annual Performance Report). The sports equipment was delivered to Colombo in December 2012, and on 18 January 2013 Ambassador Wu Jianghao and the Sri Lanka Foreign Minister Peiris signed a handover certificate (see January 2013 article from China's Ministry of Commerce).

title: China Eximbank provides $48.3 million buyer’s credit loan for Northern Road Rehabilitation Project (C2) (Linked to Project ID#71641, #71642, #71643, #71644, #71646, #71647)
description:
On April 29, 2011, China Eximbank and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $48.3 million buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreement [No. BLA 201111] for the Northern Road Rehabilitation Project (C2). This BCL carries the following terms: 6-month LIBOR plus a 2% margin, 15-year maturity, 3-year grace period, 0.5% management fee, 0.7% commitment fee, and a 6% exposure fee. The average 6 Month LIBOR rate in April 2011 was 0.442%. Total interest rate is therefore coded as 0.442% + 2.0%, or 2.442%. 
 The purpose of the Northern Road Rehabilitation Project (C2) was to rehabilitate the 67 km Navatkuli-Karaitivu-Mannar (A032) Road. C2 stands for Contract 2. China Harbour Engineering Corporation was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The preliminary works of the project commenced on November 10, 2011. The project was originally slated for completion by May 9, 2014. The activities of the project had been “substantially completed” by May 12, 2014 and handed over to Sri Lanka’s Road Development Authority. However, the project was not fully and officially complete until December 31, 2014. 
 STAFF_NOTE: This project is also known as Rehabilitation & Improvement of 67km Length of Navatkuli-Karaitivu-Mannar Road Project and the 67Km Length of Navatkuli-Karaitivu-Mannar Road (A032) - C2 Project. The Chinese project title is 北部道路改造与基建恢复项目. Some official sources identify the management fee as 0.3%.
sources: https://www.parliament.lk/uploads/documents/paperspresented/annual-report-road-development-authority-2012.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.rda.gov.lk/supported/maps/expressway_network_as_at_2019_11_07.jpg, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/images/pdf/disbursements_in_2013_jan_to_dec.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.treasury.gov.lk/documents/10181/12882/2013/99ec4ce9-183d-40ea-abfa-8331cdeee19d?version=1.0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://docplayer.net/22736118-Public-investment-supported-by-export-credit.html , Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.cbsl.gov.lk/sites/default/files/cbslweb_documents/statistics/mbt/Monthly_Bulletin_September_2010.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.mohsl.gov.lk/web/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=129%3Anorthern-road-rehabilitation-project-nrrp&catid=42%3Anational-highways-ongoing&lang=en, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://cecb.lk/project/Completed%20Projects/Roads%20and%20Bridges/Rehabilitation%20of%20Roads%20in%20the%20North.html , Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/ungc-production/attachments/cop_2015/211811/original/AEL_PLC_AR_2014-15_-_8th_Proof_28Jul15.pdf?1447734940 , Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://www.auditorgeneral.gov.lk/web/images/NothernRoadRehabilitationProject64Km201E.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.xinhuanet.com/world/2015-09/02/c_128189739.htm , Media Report, including Wikileaks
GEO_notes: Coded the Kilinochchi District since A032 runs through the capital and starts in the Navathkuli town in the district
name: Kilinochchi

title: CDB provides $100 million loan for Rehabilitation and Improvement of Priority Road Project 3 - Phase II (PRP3-II) (link to projects ID #46971, #39001 and #33402)
description: On November 24, 2014, China Development Bank (CDB) and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $100 million loan facility agreement [No. 4510201401100000587] for the Rehabilitation and Improvement of Priority Road Project 3 - Phase II (PRP3-II). This loan carried the following terms: 15 year maturity, 3 year grace period, interest rate of 6-month LIBOR plus a 2.95% margin, 0.5% management fee, and a 5.9% risk (insurance) premium. The objective of the project is to improve and rehabilitate priority road sections in Sabaragamuwa and Central Province, as well as to ensure the connectivity among already improved road sections. The following 20 roads are being rehabilitated under the Priority Road Project 3 - Phase II: 1. Katugastota-Medawala Road: 10 km (Kandy District) 2. From Thibbutta Junction to Demaralaawa-Penanetipola-Battagalla Road: 5 km (Kandy District) 3. Hapugahayatatenna-Watadeniya Road: 8 km (Kandy District) 4. Naranwita-Udadeniya-Wewatenna-Niyangama Road: 5 km (Kandy District) 5. Heennarandeniya Junction-Udiwita Elpitiya Road and Elipitiya River-Weligalla Junction: 5 km (Kandy District) 6. From Nilamba Gurukale Junction to Godawala (Doluwa Road) Starting from Kandy Galaha Main Road: 6 km (Kandy District) 7. Kotaligoda-Thismada Road: 5 km (Kandy District) 8. Eramuduliyadda-Kolugala-Thismada Road: 5 km (Kandy District) 9. Nawalapitiya-Nagaswella Road: 11 km (Kandy District) 10. From Wahugapitiya-Nuwara Eliya Road to Doragala Via Chappiliyawatta: 2 km (Kandy District) 11. Yatirawana-Balapola Road: 2 km (Kandy District) 12. A.C.S Hameed Mawatha: 0.9 km (Kandy District) 13. Mahanuwara Aruppola Mawatha No.5 (From Bakery Junction to Aruppola Junction): 0.5 km (Kandy District) 14. Rambukkana-Mawanella Road: 11.79 km (Kegalle District) 15. Bulugolla-Dombemada-Wahauwa Road: 7.65 km (Kegalle District) 16. Mawanella-Aranayaka-Horewela Road: 14.43 km (Kegalle District) 17. Gevilipitiya-Hettimulla Road: 14 km (Kegalle District) 18. Kegalle-Bulathkohupitiya-Karawanella Road: 10.35 km (Kegalle District) 19. Kegalle-Siyabalapitiya-Dewalagema Road: 2.63 km (Kegalle District) 20. Mabopitiya-Degalathiriya Road: 1.75 km (Kegalle District). The project commenced in March 2016 according to the Sri Lanka Ministry of Highways and Investment and was expected to be completed in June 2018. However, as of September 30, 2019, PRP3-II was still ongoing. Staff Note: The interest rate is coded based on the 6-month LIBOR at time of signing of the loan agreement. The average 6-month LIBOR in November 2014 was 0.327%. The total interest rate is therefore coded as 0.327% + 2.95%, or 3.277%. The Priority Road Project had three phases; see Project ID #46971 (PRP1), Project ID #39001 (PRP2), and Project ID #33402 (PRP3-Phase 1) for more details.

title: China donates LKR150m and educational materials to three schools in Sri Lanka
description: In 2011, China donated books and other educational materials to three schools in Vavuniya, Sri Lanka. The donation include a variety of books on the Chinese language, atlas, textbooks, dictionaries, wall charts and DVDs, totalling more than 600 books, and an additional 2000 exercise books. China also donated 150 million Rupees to the three schools in support of its educational activities.
sources: http://lk.china-embassy.org/chn/xwdt/t871882.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: Vavuniya district is coded for this project since the three schools that received donations are located in Vavuniya
name: Vavuniya

According to the Government of Sri Lanka’s External Resources Department (ERD), this project was completed on September 9, 2012.

name: Vavuniya

title: China Exim Bank loans Sri Lanka 13B Rs. for Lower Mulwathu Oya reservoir project
description:
In 2016, Exim Bank of China agreed to provide a 13 billion Rs. loan for the Lower Mulwathu Oya Multi Sector Development Project in the Anuradhapura and Vavuniya Districts. 13,215 ha of lands will be irrigated benefiting 10,000 farm families. 
This project envisages construction of 209 MCM capacity reservoir, 3,590 m long earth dam, Radial Gated Spillway, Left Bank, Right Bank and River Sluices, canal systems to new settlement area, and a power house. Stored water at proposed reservoir is released through the river sluice to the Malwathu Oya and picked up at Tekkam Anicut (24 Km d/s from Proposed Malwathu Oya Reservoir). From Tekkam Anicut 500 Cusec and 250 Cusec capacity right bank and left bank canals respectively convey water to irrigate 24,450 acres and 6,230 acres under existing Giant’s tank and Akitamuruppu tank respectively. 2,000 acres of new irrigable lands just downstream of the Reservoir is proposed for introducing commercial farming and 675 acres of lands have been identified for paddy cultivation. Other expected benefits are the provision of 2.0 MCM of domestic water annually for the new settlers, generation of 4.28 GWH Hydro power energy annually and the improvement of agricultural activities, livestock development, and other infrastructure development.
As of 2016, EIA had already been completed and cabinet approval had been obtained for implementation with CAMCE - China. Technical and financial proposals have been called from CAMC Company LTD for an EPC contract. MSD approval has been obtained for initial project carder. According to "Progress of development projects and programmes being implemented in 2017," only 15% of land surveying has been completed and financial progress is very low. The construction of the Malwathu Oya reservoir is expected to commence in the first quarter of 2018.
STAFF_NOTE: The concessionality of this loan is unknown, so flow class was coded as Vague (Official Finance).
sources: http://www.pmm.gov.lk/resources/mid%20year-2016.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.dailynews.lk/2018/09/17/local/162770/malwathu-oya-reservoir-work-delayed, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.ft.lk/columns/Lower-Malwathu-Oya-project-%E2%80%93-A-series-of-misconception-errors/4-639380, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.parliament.lk/uploads/documents/paperspresented/performance-report-ministry-of-irrigation-water-resources-management-2016.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.pmm.gov.lk/resources/Final%20Document-%20English.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.pmm.gov.lk/resources/Progress%20of%20the%20Projects%20Implemented%20through%20the%20Capital%20Budget%20in%20the%20year%202016_EN%20full.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.pmm.gov.lk/resources/Development_Performance_2014_End.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: Vavuniya is coded in this row. The project description and source mention that the creation of this resevoir will be located in Vavuniya and impact the district. The ADM2 was coded on QGIS.
name: Vavuniya

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 15 million grant for Supply of 8 Mobile Screening Laboratories for the Chronic Kidney Disease in North Central Province
description: On April 7, 2016, the Chinese Government and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a RMB 15 million grant agreement (“letters of exchange”) for the supply 8 mobile screening laboratories for chronic kidney disease in North Central Province. As of the end of 2019, there was no evidence that that project had entered implementation. According to the Department of External Resources, the project was completed on April 20, 2019. Staff_Note: The mobile screening laboratories are sometimes also called mobile screening ambulances.

title: China Development Bank provides $214.2 million loan for Moragahakanda Development Project
description:
On June 28, 2012, China Development Bank Corporation (CDB) signed a $214.2 million loan agreement [ID# 4510201201100000017] with the Government of Sri Lanka for the Moragahakanda Development Project. The loan carried the following terms: a variable interest rate of 6-month LIBOR + a 2.90% margin, a grace period of 4 years, a 16 year maturity, a 0.5% management fee, and a 5.9% risk (insurance) premium. 
The interest rate of the CDB loan that supported this project is coded based on the 6-month LIBOR at time of signing of the loan agreement. The average 6-month LIBOR rate in June 2012 was 0.736%. The interest rate was therefore coded as 0.736% + 2.90%, or 3.636%.
The purpose of the project, which is also known as the Construction of Head Work of Moragahakanda Reservoir Project and the "Three Gorges Project in Sri Lanka," was to provide water for irrigation purposes for those living in northern region of Sri Lanka. Another goal of the project was to supply drinking water to millions of local people. It is also expected to generate 20 megawatts of power, addressing a long-term need for domestic and industrial electricity demand in the north-central, northern and eastern provinces. 
To achieve these goals, a 61m high and 465m long dam was constructed and reservoir was impounded. Upon completion, it was expected that the Moragahakanda reservoir would hold 570 million cubic metres (MCM) of water covering an extent of 2,950 hectares. The intended beneficiaries of this project are people living in Anuradhapura, Polonnaruwa, Mathale, and Trincomalee districts. 
Sinohydro was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on January 25, 2012. A groundbreaking ceremony took place in February 2013. On May 31, 2017 the four units of the Moragahakanda Dam completed debugging ahead of grid connection. Reservoir impoundment took place on January 11, 2017. An official project completion ceremony was organized on January 8, 2018. 
The Moragahakanda dam is located across the Amban River at Elahera, in the Matale District of Sri Lanka. Its locational coordinates are 07°41′56″N 80°46′12″E. The intended beneficiaries of the Moragahakanda Development Project, which included the construction of the dam and other activities, were people living in Anuradhapura, Polonnaruwa, Mathale, and Trincomalee districts.
This project is sometimes also referred to as the Moragahakanda Kalu Ganga Multipurpose Development Project.

title: Provision of Sporting Goods for Youth in Jaffna, Kilinochchi and Mullaitivu
description: On 4 May 2012, the Chinese government signed a 1 million CNY grant agreement with Sri Lanka for the provision of sporting goods for the youth in Jaffna, Kilinochchi and Mullaitivu (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 2012 Annual Performance Report). The sports equipment was delivered to Colombo in December 2012, and on 18 January 2013 Ambassador Wu Jianghao and the Sri Lanka Foreign Minister Peiris signed a handover certificate (see January 2013 article from China's Ministry of Commerce).

title: China Eximbank provides $31.6 million buyer’s credit loan for Procurement of Material for the Northern Province Power Sector Development Programme (Uthuru Wasanthaya)
description:
On September 9, 2010, China Eximbank and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $31,659,391.82 buyer’s credit loan (BCL) for the Procurement of Material for the Northern Province Power Sector Development Programme (Uthuru Wasanthaya). The BCL carried the following terms: an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR + a 2.8% margin, 12 year maturity, 2 year grace period, 0.7% commitment fee, and 0.5% management fee. 
 The average 6-month LIBOR rate in September 2010 was 0.478%. The total interest rate is therefore coded as 0.478% + 2.80%, or 3.278%. The proceeds from the BCL were to be used to procure materials for the provision of electricity to 80,000 consumers living in Northern Province by constructing 400 rural electrification schemes. 
 China National Complete Plant Import & Export Corporation (COMPLANT) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Its work was overseen by the Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB). According to the Government of Sri Lanka’s External Resources Department (ERD), this project was completed on September 9, 2012. 
 However, this project has been plagued by controversy. A fraud investigation revealed that the contractor provided substantially fewer materials than it was contractually obligated to provide.

title: CDB provides $500 million loan for Rehabilitation and Improvement of Priority Road Project 2 (PRP2) (Linked to Project ID #46971, #33402 and #39002)
description: On March 31, 2011, China Development Bank and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $500 million loan facility agreement (No. 4500062212011110472) for the Rehabilitation and Improvement of Priority Road Project 2 (PRP2). This loan carries the following terms: 15 year maturity, 4 year grace period, interest rate of 6-month LIBOR pus a 2.9% margin, 0.5% management fee, 3.26% risk (insurance) premium. The first tranche of escrow funding (worth $326 million) was received by the Central Bank of Sri Lanka on June 29, 2011 and second tranche of escrow funding (worth $174 million) was on 28th October 28, 2011. The total cost of the PRP2 was $556 million. 90% of the project cost was covered by CDB and approximately 10% of the project cost was provided by the Government of Sri Lanka. The purpose of the project to rehabilitate and improve 581 km in 20 roads, including 95 km of provincial roads in Nuwara Eliya district, construction of two flyovers and reconstruction and widening of 22 bridges under two components (see Development Performance Report Year End Review 2015 from the Sri Lanka Department of Project Management). The 24 project components listed below include the 20 road sections, the 2 flyovers, and the 2 bridge components. This project included 24 components: 1. Horawela-Pelawatte-Pitigala Road: 0.0 - 17.50 km 2. Horana-Anguruwatota-Aluthgama Road: 5.0 - 32.0 km (total length of 27.0 km) 3. Horawela-Pelawatta-Pitigala Road: 17.5 - 25.74 km (total length of 8.24 km) 4. Construction of a flyover at Mattala airport access road junction in Hambantota Hub Development. 5. Construction of a flyover at 100 feet road and bypass road junction in Hambantota Hub Development. 6. Reconstruction/widening of Bridges on Tiruwanaketiya-Agalawatta Road: 33.45 - 67.80 km (total length of 34.35 km) 7. Reconstruction/widening of Bridges on Horana-Anguruwayoya-Aluthgama Road: 5.0 - 32.0 km (total length of 27.0 km) 8. Thihagoda-Kamburupitiya-Mawarala-Kotapola Road: 23.0 - 67.0 km (total length of 44.0 km) 9. Hungama-Middeniya Road: 0.0 - 30.0 km 10. Nagoda-Kalawellawa-Bellapitiya Road: 27.0 - 57.0 km (total length of 30.0 km) This project included the following components in the Northern Zone (see Sri Lanka Department of External Resources 'Resource Mobilization'): 11. Kandy-Mahiyangana-Padiyathalawa Road: 93.15 - 102.28 km (total length of 9.13 km) 12. Badulla-Karamatiya-Andaulpotha Road: 0.0 - 48 km 13. Mahiyangana-Dimbulagala-Daukkane Road: 0.0 - 24.10 km 14. Bibile-Uraniya-Mahiyangana Road: 22.0 - 39.58 km (total length of 17.58 km) 15. Galkulama-Anuradhapura Road: 0.0 - 15.0 km & 16.0 - 16.64 km (total length of 15.64 km) 16. Kadahapoka-Rambawewa Road: 0.0 - 18.71 km 17. Kurunegala-Narammala-Madampe Road: 0.0 - 22.36 km 18. Galagedara-Rambukkana Road: 0.0 - 18.5 km 19. Tennekumbura-Rikillagaskada-Ragala Road: 20.2 - 73.64 km (total length of 53.44 km) 20. Uswetakeiyawa-Epamulla-Pamunugama Road: 0.0 - 8.05 km 21. Palaviya-Kalpitiya Road: 14.0 - 40.60 km (total length of 26.60 km) 22. Mahiyangana-Dimbulagala-Dalukkane Road: 24.10 - 72.8 km (total length of 48.7 km) 23. Manampitiya-Aralaganwila-Maduru Oya Road: 0.0 - 3.0 km 24. Provincial Roads in Nuwaraeliya District: 85.01 km. Xi'an Dagang Road Machinery Co. Ltd., China National Aero Technology International Engineering Corporation, and Hunan Construction Engineering Corporation were the three contractors responsible for project implementation. Implementation PRP2 began on June 28, 2011 and it was completed on December 31, 2014. Staff Note: The interest rate is coded based on 6-month LIBOR at time of signing of the loan agreement. The average 6-month LIBOR rate in March 2011 was 0.461%. The total interest rate is therefore coded as 0.461% + 2.90%, or 3.361%. The Priority Road Project had three phases; see Project ID #46971 (PRP1), Project ID #33402 (PRP3-Phase 1), and Project ID #39002 (PRP3-Phase 2) for more details.

title: CDB provides $100 million loan for Rehabilitation and Improvement of Priority Road Project 3 - Phase II (PRP3-II) (link to projects ID #46971, #39001 and #33402)
description: On November 24, 2014, China Development Bank (CDB) and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $100 million loan facility agreement [No. 4510201401100000587] for the Rehabilitation and Improvement of Priority Road Project 3 - Phase II (PRP3-II). This loan carried the following terms: 15 year maturity, 3 year grace period, interest rate of 6-month LIBOR plus a 2.95% margin, 0.5% management fee, and a 5.9% risk (insurance) premium. The objective of the project is to improve and rehabilitate priority road sections in Sabaragamuwa and Central Province, as well as to ensure the connectivity among already improved road sections. The following 20 roads are being rehabilitated under the Priority Road Project 3 - Phase II: 1. Katugastota-Medawala Road: 10 km (Kandy District) 2. From Thibbutta Junction to Demaralaawa-Penanetipola-Battagalla Road: 5 km (Kandy District) 3. Hapugahayatatenna-Watadeniya Road: 8 km (Kandy District) 4. Naranwita-Udadeniya-Wewatenna-Niyangama Road: 5 km (Kandy District) 5. Heennarandeniya Junction-Udiwita Elpitiya Road and Elipitiya River-Weligalla Junction: 5 km (Kandy District) 6. From Nilamba Gurukale Junction to Godawala (Doluwa Road) Starting from Kandy Galaha Main Road: 6 km (Kandy District) 7. Kotaligoda-Thismada Road: 5 km (Kandy District) 8. Eramuduliyadda-Kolugala-Thismada Road: 5 km (Kandy District) 9. Nawalapitiya-Nagaswella Road: 11 km (Kandy District) 10. From Wahugapitiya-Nuwara Eliya Road to Doragala Via Chappiliyawatta: 2 km (Kandy District) 11. Yatirawana-Balapola Road: 2 km (Kandy District) 12. A.C.S Hameed Mawatha: 0.9 km (Kandy District) 13. Mahanuwara Aruppola Mawatha No.5 (From Bakery Junction to Aruppola Junction): 0.5 km (Kandy District) 14. Rambukkana-Mawanella Road: 11.79 km (Kegalle District) 15. Bulugolla-Dombemada-Wahauwa Road: 7.65 km (Kegalle District) 16. Mawanella-Aranayaka-Horewela Road: 14.43 km (Kegalle District) 17. Gevilipitiya-Hettimulla Road: 14 km (Kegalle District) 18. Kegalle-Bulathkohupitiya-Karawanella Road: 10.35 km (Kegalle District) 19. Kegalle-Siyabalapitiya-Dewalagema Road: 2.63 km (Kegalle District) 20. Mabopitiya-Degalathiriya Road: 1.75 km (Kegalle District). The project commenced in March 2016 according to the Sri Lanka Ministry of Highways and Investment and was expected to be completed in June 2018. However, as of September 30, 2019, PRP3-II was still ongoing. Staff Note: The interest rate is coded based on the 6-month LIBOR at time of signing of the loan agreement. The average 6-month LIBOR in November 2014 was 0.327%. The total interest rate is therefore coded as 0.327% + 2.95%, or 3.277%. The Priority Road Project had three phases; see Project ID #46971 (PRP1), Project ID #39001 (PRP2), and Project ID #33402 (PRP3-Phase 1) for more details.

name: Kandy

title: China Development Bank provides $214.2 million loan for Moragahakanda Development Project
description:
On June 28, 2012, China Development Bank Corporation (CDB) signed a $214.2 million loan agreement [ID# 4510201201100000017] with the Government of Sri Lanka for the Moragahakanda Development Project. The loan carried the following terms: a variable interest rate of 6-month LIBOR + a 2.90% margin, a grace period of 4 years, a 16 year maturity, a 0.5% management fee, and a 5.9% risk (insurance) premium. 
The interest rate of the CDB loan that supported this project is coded based on the 6-month LIBOR at time of signing of the loan agreement. The average 6-month LIBOR rate in June 2012 was 0.736%. The interest rate was therefore coded as 0.736% + 2.90%, or 3.636%.
The purpose of the project, which is also known as the Construction of Head Work of Moragahakanda Reservoir Project and the "Three Gorges Project in Sri Lanka," was to provide water for irrigation purposes for those living in northern region of Sri Lanka. Another goal of the project was to supply drinking water to millions of local people. It is also expected to generate 20 megawatts of power, addressing a long-term need for domestic and industrial electricity demand in the north-central, northern and eastern provinces. 
To achieve these goals, a 61m high and 465m long dam was constructed and reservoir was impounded. Upon completion, it was expected that the Moragahakanda reservoir would hold 570 million cubic metres (MCM) of water covering an extent of 2,950 hectares. The intended beneficiaries of this project are people living in Anuradhapura, Polonnaruwa, Mathale, and Trincomalee districts. 
Sinohydro was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on January 25, 2012. A groundbreaking ceremony took place in February 2013. On May 31, 2017 the four units of the Moragahakanda Dam completed debugging ahead of grid connection. Reservoir impoundment took place on January 11, 2017. An official project completion ceremony was organized on January 8, 2018. 
The Moragahakanda dam is located across the Amban River at Elahera, in the Matale District of Sri Lanka. Its locational coordinates are 07°41′56″N 80°46′12″E. The intended beneficiaries of the Moragahakanda Development Project, which included the construction of the dam and other activities, were people living in Anuradhapura, Polonnaruwa, Mathale, and Trincomalee districts.
This project is sometimes also referred to as the Moragahakanda Kalu Ganga Multipurpose Development Project.

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 15 million grant for Supply of 8 Mobile Screening Laboratories for the Chronic Kidney Disease in North Central Province
description: On April 7, 2016, the Chinese Government and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a RMB 15 million grant agreement (“letters of exchange”) for the supply 8 mobile screening laboratories for chronic kidney disease in North Central Province. As of the end of 2019, there was no evidence that that project had entered implementation. According to the Department of External Resources, the project was completed on April 20, 2019. Staff_Note: The mobile screening laboratories are sometimes also called mobile screening ambulances.
sources: http://www.pmm.gov.lk/resources/ENGLISH_FULL_2017.12.31.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.pmm.gov.lk/resources/Third_quarter_2017-new.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.health.gov.lk/moh_final/english/public/elfinder/files/publications/2019/AAP%202018.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient); http://treasury.gov.lk/documents/10181/693643/aprvd_V_02_English_finalEdit.pdf/3f31cd35-490e-400e-bb41-fd8174d5a8cb, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.dropbox.com/s/zy1bd8v8mg6ccp0/Supplying%20an%20MRI%20Scanner%20to%20the%20Ragama%20Teaching%20Hospital.pdf?dl=0, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.media.gov.lk/media-gallery/latest-news/1279-yuan-500-million-chinese-bonanza, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.health.gov.lk/moh_final/english/public/elfinder/files/publications/2019/FINAL%20AAP%202019.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.cabinetoffice.gov.lk/cab/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=16&Itemid=49&lang=en&dID=9789, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.news.lk/news/business/item/14873-china-to-assist-kidney-patients-in-sri-lanka, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.cbsl.gov.lk/sites/default/files/cbslweb_documents/statistics/mbt/bulletin_2016_04e.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.dropbox.com/s/z016ir7owmbcrt8/Supply%20of%208%20Mobile%20Screening%20Laboratories%20for%20the%20Chronic%20Kidney%20Disease%20in%20North%20Central%20Province.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

name: Polonnaruwa

title: China Eximbank provides $32.4 million buyer’s credit loan for the Lighting Sri Lanka Eastern Province Project (Negenahira Nawodaya) Project
description:
On January 16, 2012, China Eximbank and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $32,496,000 buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreement [China Eximbank loan identification number: 2010002032012210071] for the Lighting Sri Lanka Eastern Province Project (Negenahira Nawodaya). The BCL carried the following terms: a 15-year maturity, 4-year grace period, variable interest rate of 6-month LIBOR + a 3.00% margin, a 0.25% commitment fee, a 0.25% management fee, and a 0.55% exposure fee. The average 6 Month LIBOR rate in January 2012 was 0.797%. Total interest rate is therefore coded as 0.797% + 3.00%, or 3.797%. The BCL went into effect on July 25, 2012. 
 The purpose of this project was to supply and deliver the imported materials required for the Lighting Sri Lanka Eastern Province Project (Negenahira Nawodaya). The project involved the procurement of materials for the construction of new electrification schemes (268 new rural electrification schemes), 106 new low voltage distribution substations, 802 km of low voltage lines, and 273 km of medium voltage reinforcement tower lines and rehabilitation of 200 of low voltage distribution substations. The goal of the project was to electrify 268 villages in the Trincomalee & Batticaloa Districts. The contractor responsible for project implementation was Shanghai Electric Power Transmission & Distribution Engineering Co. Ltd. It signed an EPC contract with Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) on February 21, 2011. 
 This project was completed on January 16, 2015. 
 STAFF_NOTE: This project is also known as the Lighting Eastern Province Project. The Chinese project title is 斯里兰卡东部省配网供货项目.
sources: http://www.erd.gov.lk/index.php?option=com_rmobilization&view=resource_project&category_id=1&sub_category_id=1&searchby=donor_type&donor_id=4&today=2018-10-23&Itemid=321&lang=en, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.cabinetoffice.gov.lk/cab/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=16&Itemid=49&lang=en&dID=4294, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://powermin.gov.lk/english/?page_id=1410, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/images/pdf/performance_report_2012_english.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/images/pdf/disbursements_in_2013_jan_to_dec.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.ceb.lk/front_img/img_reports/1532060257CEB_Annual_Report_2011_(English).pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://web.archive.org/web/20180107040947/http://www.erd.gov.lk/files/Parliament%20Question%20-%20Export%20Credit%2022.052014.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.treasury.gov.lk/documents/63299/169171/Financial-Stataements-Y+2018-full.pdf/ed502d60-5ae7-4fb1-941f-1b813772923c , Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.shanghai-electric.com/group/c/2019-09-25/540639.shtml , Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://220.247.247.85:8081/bitstream/handle/123456789/18750/003_1916_April-June_6788_I_E.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y and http://europe.chinadaily.com.cn/business/2011-11/21/content_14133038.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.lankabusinessonline.com/sri-lanka-eastern-villages-lit-up-by-china/ , Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.erd.gov.lk/images/pdf/disbursements_in_2013_jan_to_dec.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
GEO_notes: Trincomalee District is coded in this row. The purpose of this project is to provide electricity to about 30,000 rural households in Baticaloa and Trincomalee Districts.
name: Trincomalee

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 577 million government concessional loan for Consultancy Services for Extension of Southern Expressway Project (Linked to Project ID #38337, #53526, #33488 and #53522)
description: On January 22, 2017, China Eximbank and the Government of Sri Lanka signed an RMB 577 million government concessional loan (GCL) agreement with Sri Lanka for consultancy services related to design review and construction supervision of civil works on the Extension of Southern Expressway Project (ESEP). The GCL will cover the full cost of the project. It carries the following terms: a 2% interest rate, 20 year maturity, and 6 year grace period (see 2017 Annual Performance Report). The objective of ESEP is to enhance the efficiency of the transport system by linking the country's major economic centers with Colombo City and other parts of the country. The proceeds from the GCL are being used to fund the provision of consultancy services related design review and construction supervision of civil work of the Southern Expressway from Matara to Hambantota. China Railway First Survey and Design Institute Group Co. Ltd. (FSDI) is the contractor responsible for project implementation. This project entered implementation on January 22, 2017. As of March 31, 2018, the consultancy work for all four sections of ESEP was on schedule. The expected project completion date is 2022 (see 'Resource Mobilization'). For information on the four sections of ESEP (for which the consultancy services captured in Project ID#53529 will be provided), see Project ID #38337 (Section 1), Project ID #53526 (Section 2), Project ID #33488 (Section 3), and Project ID #53522 (Section 4).

title: China Eximbank provides $24.9 million buyer’s credit loan for Lighting Sri Lanka Uva Province Project (Uva Udanaya)
description:
On July 19, 2011, China Eximbank and the Government of Sri Lanka signed a $24,928,046.88 buyer’s credit loan (BCL) for the Lighting Sri Lanka Uva Province Project (Uva Udanaya). The BCL carried the following terms: an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR + a 2.8% margin, 12 year maturity, and 3 year grace period. The average 6-month LIBOR rate in July 2011 was 0.414%. The total interest rate is therefore coded as 0.414% + 2.80%, or 3.214%. 
 The purpose of this project was to procure materials required for the construction of 250 new substations, 625 km of new MV lines & 2250km new low voltage lines in Moneragala and Badulla districts within Uva Province. China National Complete Plant Import & Export Corporation (COMPLANT) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. According to the Government of Sri Lanka’s External Resources Department (ERD), this project was completed on July 19, 2013. 
 STAFF_NOTE: This project is also known as the Lighting Uva Province Project.
sources: http://www.erd.gov.lk/files/performance%20report%202011%20-%20english%20version.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/files/Parliament%20Question%20-%20Export%20Credit%2022.052014.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/files/Parliament%20Question%20-%20Export%20Credit%2022.052014.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/index.php?option=com_rmobilization&view=resource_project&category_id=1&sub_category_id=1&searchby=donor_type&donor_id=4&today=2018-10-23&Itemid=321&lang=en, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/images/pdf/global_partnership_towards_development_2013.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/7i79kabduklk5ms/dec_headers3.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.dropbox.com/s/403cn9dbou1nmdy/Lighting%20Sri%20Lanka%20Uva%20Province%20Project%20%28Uva%20Udanaya%29.pdf?dl=0, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://archives.dailynews.lk/2011/02/17/news11.asp, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://pronto-core-cdn.prontomarketing.com/581/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2018/06/Menaka-Rajaguru-A-Forward-March-towards-an-Energy-Empowered-Nation-Case-Study-in-Sri-Lanka.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/images/pdf/disbursements_in_2013_jan_to_dec.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/images/pdf/disbursements_in_2013_jan_to_dec.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.erd.gov.lk/images/pdf/disbursements_in_2013_jan_to_dec.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://web.archive.org/web/20180107040947/http://www.erd.gov.lk/files/Parliament%20Question%20-%20Export%20Credit%2022.052014.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://web.archive.org/web/20180107040947/http://www.erd.gov.lk/files/Parliament%20Question%20-%20Export%20Credit%2022.052014.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

title: China granted 50 million RMB in construction aid to Sri Lanka
description: On November 19, 2010, the Chinese government agreed to provide Sri Lanka 50 million yuan in aid to strengthen bilateral relations. The sum will be used for construction projects, but specific projects have yet to be agreed upon. The agreement was signed when the Chinese National People's Congress Vice Chairman Sang Guowei visited Sri Lanka from November 17-20, 2010. In February 2011, the grant was provided to the Sri Lankan government.

title: China provides 15 million yuan Tsunami Relief Supplies to Sri Lanka (Batch 2 of 3) (Linked to #33234, #33240)
description: In January 2005, China donated relief good worth 15 million yuan (around $1.83 million) include blankets, tents, bed sheets, medicines, mosquito nets, generators, biscuits and other food. This donation is for Sri Lankan tsunami-hit areas. This was the second of three batches of relief supplies (see #33234, #33240). title: Chinese Government provides RMB 20 million grant for to Sri Lankan flood victims
description: On May 31, 2016, the Chinese Government donated 1,000 tents and 2,998 folding beds to the Government of Sri Lanka to support flood victims. The donation was worth RMB 20 million. During the donation ceremony, the Chinese Government also announced it would donate $1.5 million in cash and the funds would be used to construct a friendship village (See Project ID#53659). At the same time, the China Red Cross Society donated $50,000 to the Sri Lanka Red Cross Society for humanitarian relief activities (Project #53706). Staff_Note: The amount field was changed in October 2018 from RMB 15 million, which was based on Factiva sources.

title: China donates heavy machinery and equipment to Sri Lanka for post-war reconstruction
description: In 2010, China signed a transfer certificate with Sri Lanka regarding the donation of heavy machinery and equipment. China donated 34 heavy machinery and equipment worth over 285.4 million Sri Lanka Rupees for infrastructure development in north and east Sri Lanka. The equipment will be used for the rehabilitation and reconstruction of war-torn areas.

title: China provides humanitarian aids worth RMB 15 million to Sri Lanka for flood disasters (Linked to Project ID #53710)
description: On May 28, 2017, Chinese embassy agreed to provided humanitarian supplies worth 15 million yuan to Sri Lanka after the flood and landslide. The supplies include 600 tents, 20 thousand blankets, 5000 sheets, 20,000 life jackets, and 1,000 pairs of rain boots. According to the Economic and Commercial Counsellor’s Office (ECCO) of the Chinese Embassy source, an airplane with the relief supplies arrived in Sri Lanka on June 3, 2017. China Red Cross Society also provided US$100,000 in emergency humanitarian cash assistance and will send a working group to the local area to assist in disaster relief (captured by project ID #53710).

title: China donates 10 million yuan of humanitarian aid for flood relief in Sri Lanka (Linked to #71652 and #38917)
description: On January 18, 2011, the Chinese government agreed to grant 10 million yuan worth of humanitarian aid to flood-ravaged Sri Lanka. On January 25, 2011, the handover ceremony was held for the 70 tons worth of materials, including 30,000 bags of milk powder, 30,000 bags of sugar, 10,000 pieces towel, 10,000 bed sheet, 7,200 blankets and 60 sets of water purifiers. STAFF_NOTE: The project is related to project #71652, which captured another humanitarian aid from China government in February 2011 for flood relief in Sri Lanka, and project #38917, which captured the $30,000 donation from China's Red Cross Society to flood victims.

title: China gives Sri Lanka 270 tons of canned fish worth $320,000 USD as part of its tsunami relief efforts
description: On June 29, 2005, China granted 270 tons of canned fish worth $320,000 USD to Sri Lanka as part of its tsunami relief efforts. The aid was administered by the World Food Programme (WFP). It is the first of two such shipments, worth a total of US$1 million, to support WFP food-for-work schemes to help Sri Lanka after the tsunami. STAFF_NOTES: China contributed 63 million USD for tsunami relief in total, most of the individual projects are captured (see projects linked with resource #41811).

title: China donates 50M rupees worth of de-mining detectors and equipment to Sri Lanka
description: In March 2010, China donated a stock of de-mining equipment worth 50 million rupees to Sri Lanka to help de-mining activities in the Northern region. Chinese Ambassador to Sri Lanka Yang Xiuping handed over 50 de-mining detectors and 50 de-mining protective equipment kits to Sri Lanka Prime Minister Rathnasiri Wickramanayaka. The donation is expected to accelerate ongoing army de-mining operations in the north as part of resettlement, reconstruction, and rehabilitation efforts taking place under the 'Uthuru Wasanthaya' (Northern Spring) program.
